questions.text: A patient presents to the casualty with a chronic dry cough with no fever or other associated symptoms.  He had recently been started on an antihypertensive for hypertension. Which among the following is most likely responsible to cause these symptoms?
questions.solution:
Chronic dry cough is a common adverse effect of ACE inhibitors that occurs due to the accumulation of bradykinin, substance P, or prostaglandins in the lungs.

ACE has structural similarities to another enzyme called kininase. Kininase normally metabolizes bradykinin, substance P, and prostaglandins. ACE inhibitors when administered also block kininase enzymes which results in an increase in the concentration of these substrates. An increase in the level of bradykinin/ substance P levels results in persistent brassy cough and angioedema in the patients.

Adverse effects of ACE inhibitors:

  • Hypotension: care should be undertaken in patients who are on multiple antihypertensive drugs or have congestive heart failure.
  • Cough: dry cough due to the accumulation of bradykinin, substance P, or prostaglandins, once they are stopped symptoms disappear after around 4 days.
  • Hyperkalemia: in renal insufficiency, diabetes, or patients taking K+ sparing diuretics.
  • Acute renal failure: In patients with bilateral renal artery stenosis, heart failure, diuretics use.
  • Angioedema: rapid swelling in the nose, throat, mouth, glottis, larynx, lips, or tongue. It is an emergency and treatment is by protecting the airway and administering epinephrine, glucocorticoids, and antihistamines.
  • Fetal abnormalities mostly in the 3rd trimester of pregnancy, cause renal developmental defects.
  • Others: Skin rashes, dysgeusia, neutropenia, glycosuria, anemia, hepatotoxicity,

questions.text: A 55-year-old man comes with complaints of fever and increasing fatigue for the past week. On examination, he is febrile, hypotensive and tachycardic. The findings of microscopic examination of his peripheral blood smear is given below. What is the causative agent?
questions.solution:
The given clinical history and the blood smear showing multiple ring forms in RBCs are suggestive of Plasmodium falciparum.

Plasmodium falciparum causes malignant tertian malaria. This means that the fever has a periodicity of 48 hours corresponding to one cycle of erythrocytic schizogony. Malignant because it is a more severe and fatal type of malaria.

Major manifestations of severe falciparum malaria include unarousable coma/ cerebral malaria (failure to localize or respond appropriately to stimuli or coma persisting for >30 min after generalized convulsion), acidosis, severe normocytic normochromic anemia, renal failure, pulmonary edema, hypoglycemia, shock, and disseminated intravascular coagulation. Other manifestations include hemoglobinuria, hyperparasitemia, jaundice, and extreme weakness.

Falciparum malaria shows a very high percentage of RBCs containing ring forms. This high-level parasitemia is more often seen in Plasmodium falciparum infection than in infection by other plasmodia. After the ring form in the peripheral blood, the rest of the erythrocytic cycle occurs in the capillaries of the brain and internal organs. So, only ring forms can be seen in the peripheral blood and not the late trophozoites and schizonts. The gametocytes of P. falciparum are crescent-shaped or “banana-shaped” (as shown below), whereas those of the other plasmodia are spherical.

The treatment of choice is artesunate given at a dose of 2.4 mg/kg stat IV, followed by 2.4 mg/kg at 12 and 24 hours, and then daily if necessary.

In Plasmodium falciparum, recrudescence can be seen which is defined as the recurrence of asexual parasitemia. It usually occurs within 8 weeks of treatment and is due to incomplete treatment or drug resistance.

questions.text: What is the structure marked in the image below?
questions.solution:
The structure marked in the image is the Genioglossus muscle.

Genioglossus is one of the extrinsic muscles of the tongue which bring about the forward traction of the tongue to protrude its apex from the mouth. Hence, it is also called the safety muscle of the tongue.

Origin: The superior mental spine (also called the superior genial tubercle) of the mandible, located on the internal surface of the mandible near the symphysis (midline).
Insertion: The muscle fans out and inserts into the entire length of the inferior surface of the tongue and the body of the hyoid bone.

Acting bilaterally, the two muscles depress the central part of the tongue, making it concave from side to side. Acting unilaterally, the tongue diverges to the opposite side.

Other options:

Option B: Hyoglossus: depresses the tongue

Option C: Styloglossus: draws the tongue up and backward.

Option D: Palataglossus: elevate the posterior portion of the tongue

All muscles of tongue are derived from occipital myotomes, hence innervated by hypoglossal nerve, except palatoglossus which is derived from the pharyngeal arch and is supplied by vago-accessory nerve.

questions.text: Which of the following enzymes is deficient in the autosomal recessive type of severe combined immunodeficiency?
questions.solution:
Adenosine deaminase (ADA) deficiency is the first immunodeficiency disease associated with enzyme deficiency in SCID (Severe combined immunodeficiency).

Severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID)

  • Defects in both humoral and cell-mediated immune responses.
  • Affected infants present with prominent thrush (oral candidiasis), extensive diaper rash, and failure to thrive.
  • Some patients develop a morbilliform rash shortly after birth because maternal T cells are transferred across the placenta and attack the fetus, causing graft-versus-host disease (GVHD).
  • Persons with SCID are extremely susceptible to recurrent, severe infections by a wide range of pathogens, including Candida albicans, Pneumocystis jiroveci, Pseudomonas species, cytomegalovirus, varicella, and a host of other bacteria.

Autosomal recessive

  • The most common cause of autosomal-recessive SCID is a deficiency of the enzyme adenosine deaminase (ADA).
  • Deficiency of ADA leads to the accumulation of deoxyadenosine and its derivatives (e.g., deoxy-ATP), which are toxic to rapidly dividing immature lymphocytes, especially those of the T-cell lineage. Hence, there may be a greater reduction in the number of T lymphocytes than of B lymphocytes.
  • In the two most common forms (γc mutation and ADA deficiency), the thymus is small and devoid of lymphoid cells.
  • In SCID caused by ADA deficiency, remnants of Hassall’s corpuscles can be found.

X-linked SCID.

  • The most common form, accounting for 50% to 60% of cases, is X-linked, and hence, SCID is more common in boys than in girls.
  • The genetic defect in the X-linked form is a mutation in the common γ-chain (γc) subunit of cytokine receptors.  
  • X-linked SCID is the first human disease in which gene therapy has been successful.     

Other options:

Option A: Ornithine transcarbamylase deficiency leads to hyperammonemia type II. Orotic aciduria occurs due to the redirection of carbamoyl phosphate into pyrimidine synthesis.

Option B: Phosphomannose isomerase deficiency is a disorder of glycosylation and features include failure to thrive, enteropathy, and hepatic fibrosis.

Option D: Hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyl transferase (HPRT) enzyme deficiency leads to a disease called Lesch-Nyhan disease (LND).

questions.text: A pregnant lady presented to the casualty after she was scratched by a street dog while she was walking on the streets an hour ago. She has only some minor abrasions with no bleeding. What treatment should be offered to her?

choices.text: No treatment as she is pregnant now
Local wound cleaning and rabies vaccine
Local wound cleaning, Rabies vaccine and Immunoglobulins

questions.solution:
This case is classified under WHO category II since there was no bleeding present at the site of the dog bite and she has to be given Rabies vaccine along with local wound cleaning. 

Since Rabies is a lethal disease, there is no contraindication for post-exposure prophylaxis following high-risk exposures, even in pregnancy, infancy, immunocompromised patients, and even in children with AIDS/HIV. 

Note:

Patients taking chloroquine have to be given the vaccine intramuscularly as there is a reduced response to the intradermal route. 

For pre-exposure prophylaxis, previous allergic reaction to any components of the vaccine is a contraindication. 

Related Pearl: Rabies vaccines and immunoglobulins schedules

According to the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare, Government of India:

WHO category II or III exposures should receive post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) immediately.

One intradermal (ID) dose is 0.1 mL of vaccine and one intramuscular (IM) dose is an entire vial of vaccine, irrespective of the vial size.

Should a vaccine dose be delayed for any reason, the PEP schedule should be resumed (not restarted).

Rabies Immunoglobulin(RIG): 

  • Passive immunization
  • Single-dose; after initiation of PEP and not beyond 7 days after the first dose of vaccine
  • Max dose: hRIG - 20IU/kg , eRIG - 40IU/kg body weight
  • Vaccines should never be withheld regardless of the availability of RIG.
  • Alternatives for RIG- WHO recommends monoclonal antibodies (mAb) as a 'cocktail' containing at least two antibodies against the rabies virus.

Administration of RIG:

  • RIG should be administered into or around the wound site or sites.
  • The remaining RIG, if any, should be injected IM at a site distant from the site of vaccine administration.
  • RIG may be diluted to a volume sufficient for all wounds to be effectively and safely infiltrated.

Prioritization of RIG allocation (numbered according to priority order):

  1. Multiple bites
  2. Deep wounds
  3. Bites to head, neck, and hands
  4. Patients with severe immunodeficiency
  5. Confirmed/probable rabies in biting animal
  6. Bites, scratches, and exposure of mucous membranes caused by a bat

Pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP)

PrEP is considered in the following conditions:

  • High-risk groups- laboratory staff, wildlife wardens, veterinarians, animal handlers, and travelers to endemic regions.
  • Remote, rabies-endemic areas where access to PEP is difficult
  • Areas where dog bite incidence is >5% per year
  • Areas where vampire bat rabies is known to be present.

Pre-exposure rabies vaccination consists of two intramuscular (IM) or two intradermal (ID) doses. These are given on days 0 and 3.

  • Adults - the vaccine should always be administered in the deltoid area of the arm
  • Young children (under 1 year of age)- Administration into the anterolateral area of the thigh is recommended.
  • Rabies vaccine should never be administered in the gluteal area. Administration in this manner will result in lower neutralizing antibody titers.

For exposed or re-exposed patients who can document previous completion of PEP the following guidelines would be applicable:

  • Proper wound management should be done.
  • There is no need for the administration of RIG.
  • One site ID or IM vaccine administration on days 0 and 3.

Only adequate wound washing would be required in case of re-exposure where the animal bite victim has documented proof of complete PEP within the last three months.

The following cases are treated as fresh cases and given full PEP:

  • Those who have previously received full post-exposure treatment with neural tissue vaccines (NTV) or vaccines of unproven potency
  • Those who cannot document complete PEP or PrEP treatment

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy has been observed by his parents to be increasingly clumsy for the past 6 months. On physical examination, there is leukocoria with an absence of the red reflex in the left eye. A diagnosis was made and enucleation was done. The specimen is shown below. The microscopic appearance shows Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The histology, clinical history, and gross specimen point toward a diagnosis of retinoblastoma.

Retinoblastoma is the most common intraocular malignancy in children associated with mutations in the RB1 gene at chromosome 13q14. 

It most commonly presents with leukocoria followed by a squint which is usually convergent. Rarely, the child may present with nystagmus and defective vision.

Signs:

  • An intraretinal tumor is a homogeneous, dome-shaped white lesion that becomes irregular, often with white flecks of calcification.
  • An endophytic tumor projects into the vitreous as a white mass that may "seed" into the gel.
  • An exophytic tumor forms multilobular subretinal white masses and causes an overlying retinal detachment.

Investigations:

  • Red reflex testing with a direct ophthalmoscope is a simple screening test for leukocoria.
  • Dilated fundus examination using indirect ophthalmoscope
  • MRI of the orbit + brain is the investigation of choice.

Histopathology of the tumor shows small round cells with large nuclei. Microscopic features of a well-differentiated tumor include Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes (highly specific of retinoblastoma), Homer-Wright rosettes, pseudorosettes, and fleurettes formation. Areas of necrosis and calcification can also be seen.

Treatment typically involves chemotherapy plus focal therapy.Vincristine, Carboplatin, Etoposide are the choice of drugs for chemotherapy. Focal therapy includes cryotherapy, laser photocoagulation, thermotherapy, plaque radiotherapy, and external beam radiotherapy.
 
Enucleation is done when the tumor involves more than half of the retina, optic nerve involvement, glaucoma, and anterior chamber involvement.

questions.text: According to Sustainable Development Goals, which of the following statement is false ?

choices.text: End the epidemics of AIDS, tuberculosis, malaria and combat hepatitis
Reduce the global maternal mortality ratio to less than 70 (per 100,000 live births)
Reduce the neonatal mortality rate to as low as 25 (per 1,000 live births)
Reduce under-5 mortality to as low as 25 (per 1,000 live births)

questions.solution:
The statement "Reduce the neonatal mortality rate to as low as 25 (per 1,000 live births)" is false, and the true statement is "Reduce the neonatal mortality rate to as low as 12 (per 1,000 live births)".

SDG (Sustainable Development Goals) comprises 17 goals and 170 targets for Agenda 2030.

  • The MDGs came to an end in December 2015 and were replaced by the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs).
  • 17 SDGs take their place and as of 1st January 2016, the SDGs of the 2030 agenda for sustainable development officially came into force.
  • The five P's of the new agenda are People, Planet, Prosperity, Peace, and Partnership.

 Health is positioned in one comprehensive goal SDG 3.

  • Target 3.1: To reduce the global maternal mortality ratio to less than 70 (per 100,000 live births) 
  • Target 3.2: To reduce neonatal mortality and under-5 mortality by as low as 12 and 25 (per 1,000 live births) respectively.
  • Target 3.3: To end the epidemics of AIDS, tuberculosis, malaria, and neglected tropical diseases and combat hepatitis, water-borne diseases, and other communicable diseases.

questions.text: The elimination of phenytoin at higher doses follows____
questions.solution:
Phenytoin follows zero order kinetics because the metabolism saturates at a very low plasma level.

 Phenytoin:

  • At very low doses follows first order kinetics.
  • As the dose increases, the metabolizing enzymes get saturated and kinetics change to zero order.
  • Higher doses results in higher half life.
  • Is highly protein bound (~90%) and induces microsomal enzymes

Drugs following zero order kinetics/capacity limited elimination/Michaelis-Menten elimination:

  • Ethanol
  • Methanol

Kinetics changes from first order to zero order at higher doses for:

  • Warfarin
  • Theophylline
  • Tolbutamide
  • Phenytoin

questions.text: Which of the following stains is used for the detection of hemosiderin deposits?
questions.solution:
Perl's Prussian blue stain is used to detect hemosiderin deposits.

Hemosiderin is a hemoglobin-derived granular pigment that is golden-yellow to brown. It accumulates in the tissues when there is a local or systemic excess of iron.

Iron is normally stored within cells in association with the protein apoferritin, forming ferritin micelles. Large aggregates of these micelles are hemosiderin deposits seen both in light and electron microscopy.

questions.text: A tourist who has been travelling in India presents with complaints of abdominal pain and multiple episodes of watery diarrhea. He reports having food at a local restaurant the previous night. Which of the following antidiarrheal agents is used in this condition?
questions.solution:
The antidiarrheal agent used in the given clinical scenario is loperamide. 

The given clinical scenario of a tourist with abdominal pain, and multiple episodes of diarrhea following food intake at an unhygienic place is suggestive of traveler’s diarrhea and the serotype of E.Coli most likely responsible for these symptoms would be Enterotoxigenic E. coli (ETEC). Enterotoxigenic E.Coli is the most common cause of traveler's diarrhea. 

Loperamide is an opioid receptor agonist and slows intestinal motility by direct effects on the circular and longitudinal muscles. It reduces fecal volume and increases viscosity. It is used in traveler's diarrhea for symptomatic treatment in conjunction with antibiotics. It is avoided in patients with dysentery. 

Other options: 

Option A: Octreotide is a somatostatin analog effective in treating severe secretory diarrhea that occurs due to hormone-secreting tumors in the GIT and pancreas. Its use is limited in traveler's diarrhea. 

Option C: Rifaximin is an antibiotic used in the treatment of traveler's diarrhea. It is an alternative to Azithromycin due to poor absorption. 

Option D: Bismuth subsalicylate is an over-the-counter (OTC) preparation used as an antidiarrheal agent. It is used in the treatment of traveler's diarrhea but is not preferred over loperamide due to a requirement for large doses, and salicylate toxicity, especially in high-risk groups (pregnancy, children, and individuals who take aspirin).

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with lung adenocarcinoma comes for her chemotherapy treatment. She has had multiple complaints of nausea and vomiting during her previous treatment visits. Which of the following is used to prevent emesis and vomiting?
questions.solution:
Palonosetron is used in chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting. 

Palonosetron is a 5HT3 receptor antagonist that blocks serotonin in vagal terminals and centrally in the chemoreceptor trigger zone (CTZ). It has a higher receptor affinity as compared to the first-generation 5HT3 antagonists making it more potent. It is also useful in delayed emesis associated with chemotherapy due to its long half-life. 

During chemotherapy, there is cell lysis and 5HT(serotonin) is released from the gut mucosa. The released serotonin acts on the 5HT3 receptors and activates the vagal afferents in the gut that carry the emetogenic impulses to the nucleus tractus solitarius and chemoreceptor trigger zone. The selective blockade of 5HT3 receptors reduces the emetogenic impulses.

It is used in combination with netupitant in acute and delayed nausea and vomiting. Netupitant is an NK1 receptor antagonist. It augments the effects of palonosetron. This combination is particularly anti-emetogenic when given along with dexamethasone.

Other options:

Option A: Metoclopramide is a 5HT4 agonist and D2 blocker and is used as an antiemetic agent.

Option B: Ropinirole is an antiparkinsonian drug that is a dopamine agonist and is also the drug of choice for restless leg syndrome.

Option C: Domperidone is not used in chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting.

questions.text: Which of the following is helpful in predicting the virulence of a disease?
questions.solution:
The case fatality rate represents the killing power (or virulence) of the disease.

Case fatality rate = Total number of deaths due to a particular disease X 100 / Total number of cases due to the same disease

The case-fatality rate is thus the proportion of people with a particular disease who die from that disease. It is a measure of the severity of the disease, the deadliness of an outbreak, and may be used to evaluate any public health measures implemented. 

Due to changes in the agent, host, and environmental factors in different epidemics, the case fatality rate for the same disease may vary in different epidemics. It is typically used in acute infectious diseases. Eg: Food poisoning, measles, cholera, etc. 

The case-fatality rate is not a true rate, but actually a proportion. Hence, the term case-fatality ratio is often preferred.

Related Pearl: Case Fatality Rate

  • Case fatality rate =  (Total number of deaths due to a particular disease)/(Total number of cases due to the same disease)x 100
  • It is a good indicator of severity or killing power of a disease.
  • It is used mostly in acute and infectious diseases.
  • No time interval is used.
  • Case fatality rate is closely related to virulence.
  • Limitation of CFR is that its usefulness for chronic diseases is limited because the period from onset to death is variable.
  • It is expressed in percentage.
  • CFR is an incidence proportion and not a true rate.
  • CFR may vary for the same disease in different epidemics.

  • Case fatality of a few diseases:

    • Rabies - 100% especially after symptoms manifest
    • Ebola - 25 to 90%, average - 50% 
    • Yellow fever - 15 to 50%
    • Chicken pox - 0.001%
  • Diseases with a high case fatality rate: Tetanus, Rabies, Botulism, Ebola.
  • Diseases with a low case fatality rate: Leprosy, Trachoma, Lymphatic filariasis.

questions.text: Which of the following develops from the dorsal mesogastrium?
questions.solution:
The spleen develops from the mesoderm in the dorsal mesogastrium.

The mesenchymal cells in the dorsal mesogastrium form small lobular masses of splenic tissue called spleniculi. Later, these lobules fuse to form a single mass of the spleen. The capsule, septa, and connective tissue framework, including reticular fibers, develop from mesoderm. The mesenchymal cells also differentiate into lymphoblasts and other blood-forming cells.

When the spleen develops, the dorsal mesogastrium gets divided into an anterior segment called the gastrosplenic ligament that extends from the spleen to the stomach, and a posterior part called the lienorenal ligament that extends from the spleen to the left kidney. 

The mesenteries of the stomach include the ventral and dorsal mesogastrium. 

  • Ventral mesogastrium (Lesser omentum), where the ventral pancreatic bud, liver, and gallbladder develop
  • Dorsal mesogastrium (Greater omentum), where the spleen, celiac trunk, and dorsal pancreatic bud develop

questions.text: Nitrogenous waste is excreted from the body in the form of __?
questions.solution:
Nitrogenous wastes are excreted from the body in the form of urea.

Depending on their ecological niche and physiology, different animals excrete excess nitrogen as ammonia (in aqueous animals), uric acid (in Birds), or urea.

Many land animals, including humans, are ureotelic and excrete nontoxic, highly water-soluble urea. Since urea is non-toxic to humans, high blood levels in renal disease are a consequence, not a cause, of impaired renal function.

questions.text: Which of the following is most likely to be released from the hypothalamus?
questions.solution:
Hexokinase type IV/ glucokinase is most likely to be released from the hypothalamus.

Glucokinase, also known as hexokinase IV, catalyses the conversion of glucose to glucose-6-phosphate, which constitutes the first step of glycolysis.

The hypothalamus is an important center for the regulation of glucose homeostasis. It contains glucokinase/hexokinase IV which plays a central role in the counterregulatory response. This is a feedback system to counteract hypoglycemia by increasing the production of glucose and limiting its utilization.

There are four isoforms of hexokinase: 

  • Hexokinase type I: major isoform in the brain. 
  • Hexokinase type II: predominant in insulin-sensitive tissues such as adipose tissue, skeletal muscle, and cardiac muscle. 
  • Hexokinase type III: not predominant in any tissue.
  • Hexokinase type IV: primarily to the liver and pancreas.

questions.text: A patient presented with a black, foul-smelling discharge from the nose. On examination, a blackish necrotic mass filling the nasal cavity and eroding the septum and hard palate was seen. What is the most important risk factor for this disease?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of mucormycosis and the most important risk factor among these is diabetes.

Mucormycosis is an opportunistic mycosis. It is typically seen in patients with diabetes mellitus and immunocompromised patients. Mucormycosis recently emerged as an important superinfection in COVID-19 patients, especially in India. The surge in cases is most likely due to diabetes mellitus and steroid use.

Risk factors for the infection include the following:

  • Uncontrolled diabetes

Treatment includes intravenous administration of amphotericin B and wide excision of necrotic tissues. Along with the reversal of underlying conditions and risk factors.

questions.text: A neonate is brought with complaints of photophobia and watering. Clinical examination shows normal tear passages and clear but large cornea. The image of his eye is shown below which reveals Haab's striae. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of buphthalmos.

Buphthalmos (Bull-like eyes) is an enlargement of the eyeball seen in true congenital and infantile glaucoma, usually when the disease onset is before 3 years.

Primary congenital glaucoma (PCG) can be classified as:

  • True congenital glaucoma - IOP is elevated during intrauterine life.
  • Infantile glaucoma - manifests before 3 years of age.
  • Juvenile glaucoma (least common) -  IOP rises between 3 and 16 years of age.

Clinically, the child may present with buphthalmos. This refers to a large eye that results from stretching due to raised IOP before 3 years of age. The thin sclera appears blue due to underlying uveal tissue. Haab's striae (curvilinear healed breaks in Descemet's membrane) and corneal haze (due to diffuse edema secondary to raised IOP) may also be noted on examination. Severe cases may also result in corneal scarring.

Evaluation is done under general anesthesia. Initially, IOP measurement is performed (10–12 mmHg is normal). A corneal diameter measuring greater than 12 mm is highly suggestive for an infant under the age of 1 year.

Management is essentially surgical and goniotomy and/or trabeculotomy may be done.

questions.text: In the following natural history of disease flowchart, point A to C is called?
questions.solution:
The period between the first possible time of detection (point A) and the usual time of diagnosis (point C) is called as lead time.

Other options:

The period between the first possible time of detection (point A) and the final critical point of diagnosis (point B) is called Screening time.

Screening is the search for unrecognized diseases or defects in apparently healthy individuals by means of rapidly applicable tests or procedures. It must be done in conditions where there is a considerable time lag between the onset of the disease and the usual time of diagnosis (point C in the image).

This ensures the success of any treatment in reversing the disease process. The final critical point (point B in the image) is the stage beyond which treatment would be unsuccessful or there would be permanent damage.

Generation time is defined as the interval of time between the onset of infection by a host and the maximal infectivity of that host.

questions.text:
There are two patients, A and B. Patient A shows the following facial features: deviation of angle of mouth to left, eyelids completely closed, and wrinkling of the forehead. 
Patient B shows the following facial features: deviation of angle of mouth to left, the right eyelid is not closed, and no wrinkling of the forehead. Identify the correct type of facial palsy in both patients:

choices.text: A-Right LMN facial nerve palsy B-Left UMN facial nerve palsy
A-Right  UMN facial nerve palsy B-Right LMN facial nerve palsy
A-Left UMN facial nerve palsy B-Right LMN facial nerve palsy
A-Left LMN facial nerve palsy B-Right UMN facial nerve palsy

questions.solution:
Patient A shows - Left UMN facial nerve palsy and patient B shows - Right LMN facial nerve palsy.

Patient A: Left upper motor neuron(UMN) lesion

In this patient, the presence of wrinkling on the forehead and normal eyelid closure indicates an upper motor neuron lesion. In an upper motor neuron lesion, the contralateral side of the face is affected. And in this case, the right side of the face is affected (since the deviation of the angle of the mouth is to the left) which implies an upper motor neuron lesion on the left side. 

Patient B: Right lower motor neuron(LMN) lesion

In this patient, the absence of wrinkling on the forehead and incomplete closure of the right eyelid indicates a lower motor neuron lesion. In lower motor neuron lesions, the ipsilateral side of the face is affected. And in this case, the right side of the face is affected(since the deviation of the angle of the mouth is to the left) which implies a lower motor neuron lesion is on the right side.

Note: Deviation of the angle of mouth should not be confused with drooping of the angle of mouth. Deviation of the angle of the mouth occurs on the normal side while drooping occurs on the affected side.

questions.text: High-ceiling diuretics are used in the treatment of all of the following conditions except:
questions.solution:
High-ceiling diuretics or loop diuretics are not used in pulmonary hypertension.

Their diuretic property helps in removing the excess fluid in hepatic, renal, and cardiac diseases and their vasodilatory and diuretic action is helpful for the quick relief of symptoms in LVF and acute pulmonary edema. They are also used for the treatment of chronic CHF.

Pulmonary artery hypertension is a condition where there is increased pulmonary vascular resistance. Since nitric oxide is an important regulator of pulmonary vascular resistance, PDE5 inhibitors like sildenafil, vardenafil, or tadalafil are primarily used in the treatment of pulmonary arterial hypertension.

Other options:

Option A: Generalized edema occurs due to fluid retention in systemic tissues, commonly seen in conditions like heart failure, nephrotic syndrome, or chronic kidney disease. High-ceiling diuretics are effective here as they can rapidly reduce extracellular fluid volume by promoting diuresis.

Option B: Although loop diuretics are not the first-line treatment for cerebral edema, they may be used in conjunction with other therapies like mannitol to reduce intracranial pressure by decreasing overall fluid volume

Option C: Loop diuretics help reduce pulmonary congestion by decreasing preload and promoting diuresis.

questions.text: An elderly male patient was brought to the casualty. He has a history of progressive weakness on the right side of the body except for the leg. CT scan is shown below. Which vessel is likely to be thrombosed?
questions.solution:
The middle cerebral artery is likely to be thrombosed. A lesion in the middle cerebral artery causes contralateral hemiparesis, sparing the leg area.

  • It supplies the medial surface of the cerebral cortex and parts of lentiform, caudate nuclei, and the internal capsule.

  • It is the larger terminal branch of the internal carotid artery.
  • It runs in the lateral sulcus.
  • It supplies the entire lateral surface of the cerebral hemisphere except for a narrow strip (supplied by the anterior cerebral artery) and the occipital pole and the inferolateral surface (supplied by the posterior cerebral artery).

  • It supplies the occipital lobe, inferolateral and medial surfaces of the temporal lobe, and parts of the brainstem.

questions.text: A 55-year-old female presents with complaints of persistent headaches. A CT scan of the head reveals a brain tumour. On histopathology, psammoma bodies are seen. Based on these findings, what is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette and the histopathology showing a tumour with psammoma bodies is suggestive of meningioma.

Meningiomas are predominantly benign tumors in adults, typically attached to the dura and arising from the meningothelial cells of the arachnoid. They can develop along any external surface of the brain or within the ventricular system, originating from the stromal arachnoid cells of the choroid plexus.

A major risk factor for meningiomas is prior radiation therapy to the head and neck. The most common cytogenetic abnormality associated with these tumors is the loss of chromosome 22, particularly the long arm (22q). Meningiomas are frequently seen in neurofibromatosis type 2 (NF2), often occurring at multiple sites, especially alongside acoustic neuromas or glial tumors.

The tumor mass is usually encapsulated but may also grow en plaque, where it spreads in a sheetlike manner along the dura, often leading to hyperostotic reactive changes in the adjacent bone. Histologically, meningiomas may contain numerous calcified psammoma bodies, a characteristic microscopic feature.

Psammoma bodies are concentric, lamellated structures formed as a product of dystrophic calcification. They are associated with papillary histomorphology and are caused by infarction and calcification of papillae tips. 

The histological section of meningioma showing psammoma bodies is given below:

Histological subtypes:

  • WHO Grade I – Menigothelial, fibroblastic, transitional, psammomatous, secretory, microcystic
  • WHO Grade II- Clear cell, choroid, atypical
  • Grade III – Papillary, rhabdoid, anaplastic
  • Atypical meningiomas (WHO grade II/IV) - a higher rate of recurrence and more aggressive local growth
  • Anaplastic (malignant) meningioma (WHO grade III/IV) - highly aggressive tumor with the appearance of a high-grade sarcoma
  • Immunoreactive for epithelial membrane antigen
  • Keratin is restricted to lesions with the secretory pattern, and these tumors are also positive for carcinoembryonic antigen
  • Moderate (3: 2) female predominance, usually solitary, but when present at multiple sites, the possibility of neurofibromatosis type 2 should be considered.
  • Meningiomas often express progesterone receptors and may grow more rapidly during pregnancy.

Other Options:

Option A: Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes with arrangements of a single layer of tumor cells around an apparent lumen can be seen in Retinoblastoma.

Option B: Medulloblastoma is a malignant embryonal tumor of childhood that occurs exclusively in the cerebellum. Histologically, the tumor is very densely cellular. Individual tumor cells have scant cytoplasm and elongated or crescent-shaped hyperchromatic nuclei. Tumor cells form Homer Wright rosettes. They express neuronal markers such as synaptophysin.

Option D: Oligodendroglioma is composed of tumor cells that resemble oligodendrocytes. The tumor contains sheets of regular cells with spherical nuclei containing finely granular chromatin, surrounded by a clear halo of vacuolated cytoplasm. This gives them a fried egg appearance. They contain a network of anastomosing capillaries, resembling chicken wire and also have calcifications.

questions.text: The most common site of obstruction by a nasal polyp from the maxillary sinus is?
questions.solution:
The maxillary sinus opens into the middle meatus at the lower part of the infundibulum, in its medial wall and thus a nasal polyp will obstruct the middle meatus.

Infundibulum is the space limited medially by the uncinate process and frontal process of the maxilla, and laterally by the lamina papyracea.

  • Middle meatus: Frontal sinus, maxillary sinus, anterior ethmoidal sinus. All these together form the osteo-meatal complex or Picadle’s circle.
  • Superior meatus: Posterior ethmoidal sinus
  • Sphenoethmoidal recess: Sphenoid sinus

questions.text: Identify the fungus shown in the image given below which is stained by India ink dye.
questions.solution:
The image above shows the fungus cryptococcus.

The image shows India ink preparation which is employed to detect the presence of capsulated yeast, cryptococcus neoformans. It induces negative staining by creating a black, semi-opaque background that makes the capsule of the yeast clearly visible. Cryptococcus has a polysaccharide capsule which is demonstrated as clear halos against a black background.

Cryptococcus neoformans is an opportunistic fungus that is found worldwide as a saprophyte in soil enriched with pigeon droppings. It may cause infection in immune-competent people, resulting in a flu-like illness with complete recovery.

Infection in immunocompromised people like AIDS patients or patients with hematological malignancies results in meningoencephalitis.

Mucicarmine stain can also be used in the identification of cryptococcus. The image given below shows mucicarmine stained specimen of lung tissue containing cryptococci.

Culture on Sabouraud dextrose agar (SDA) at 37'C appears as smooth, mucoid, and creamy white. The cryptococcal antigen(in serum and CSF) is sensitive and specific and can be demonstrated by the latex agglutination test.

Treatment of cryptococcal meningitis involves a combination therapy of amphotericin B with flucytosine. Fluconazole can be added with these drugs in AIDS patients to prevent relapse.

questions.text: Which of the following is correct regarding oxytocin?

choices.text: It can be given by oral route
It is secreted by anterior pituitary
In higher doses, it exerts diuretic like action

questions.solution:
Oxytocin is responsible for galactokinesis (milk ejection reflex).

Other options:

  • It can not be given by oral route because it can cause mood disturbances 
  • It is secreted by the posterior pituitary.
  • It does not have diuretic-like action at higher doses.

WHO guidelines for active management of the third stage of labor (AMTSL) recommends oxytocin administration immediately (within 1 minute) after the delivery of the fetus.  Oxytocin 10 IU is given IM or IV. It should be given after the delivery of the fetus and before the delivery of the placenta. 

Milk ejection by oxytocin follows a stimulation mechanism similar to a uterine contraction in delivery (cervical dilatation). 

The physiological actions of oxytocin are: 

  • Contraction of the pregnant uterus: Cervical dilatation transmits signals to the hypothalamus and stimulates the secretion of oxytocin, which acts on the smooth muscles of the uterus and contracts it. 
  • Milk ejection from breasts: The suckling reflex transmits signals to the hypothalamus which causes the release of oxytocin which acts on the myoepithelial cells of the breast. This results in the ejection of milk. 

The action of oxytocin is an example of a positive feedback mechanism. 

AMTSL  guidelines recommended by WHO :

  • Immediate administration of prophylactic uterotonic (Oxytocin). Oxytocin 10 IU is given IM or IV.
  • Controlled cord traction during placental delivery (in cesarean section and in vaginal birth where skilled birth attendants are present)
  • Delayed cord clamping
  • Postpartum abdominal uterine tonus assessment for early identification of uterine atony is recommended for all women. Continuous monitoring of uterine tone is done every 15 minutes for 2 hours. If uterine atony is detected, a fundal massage is performed.

questions.text: You see a child with delayed speech development. The otoscopic appearance of the ear is shown below. Hearing loss of 20 dB is detected in audiometric tests. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and image suggest a diagnosis of serous otitis media. 

The golden yellow discoloration of the tympanic membrane is caused by the clear watery straw-colored effusion filling the middle ear. Since the fluid is clear, one can see the structures of the middle ear quite clearly on otoscopy.

Patients having serous otitis media will have hearing loss that rarely exceeds 40 dB. This deafness can pass unnoticed, and maybe accidentally discovered during audiometric screening tests. Because of hearing loss, the development of speech is delayed or defective.

Otoscopic findings in serous otitis media:

  • Fluid level and air bubbles are seen when fluid is thin and the tympanic membrane transparent.
  • In chronic cases, the fluid becomes very sticky. Hence, the name glue ear. 
  • The tympanic membrane is often dull and opaque with a loss of light reflex.
  • The mobility of the tympanic membrane is restricted.

questions.text: The  fallopian tube is lined by ______.
questions.solution:
The lining epithelium of the fallopian tube is a single layer of ciliated columnar epithelium. 

The ciliated epithelial cells are predominant in the distal part of the fallopian tube. There is an increase in the height and number of cilia in these cells during the estrogenic phase of the menstrual cycle.

Other cells in the fallopian tube epithelium include:

  • Secretory or peg cells - maximally located in the proximal portion of the tube. These cells are active around the time of ovulation, and their secretions help in the capacitation of sperms.
  • Intraepithelial lymphocytes - may present occasionally. 

Related Pearl: Various Types of Epithelium, Their Location and Functions

questions.text: Based on the disease shown in the image, which of the following specimens would the organism be absent?
questions.solution:
The image is suggestive of lymphatic filariasis, and the filarial worms cannot be demonstrated in saliva.

Lymphatic filariasis occurs due to the transmission of W.bancrofti by the bite of Culex mosquitoes. The third stage larval forms from the mosquito enter the lymphatics and lymph nodes where they develop into adult worms. The adult worms become sexually mature and mate to release microfilariae which enter the peripheral circulation.

The disease initially causes acute attacks of lymphangitis and lymphadenitis. Early treatment may even cure the disease. The lymphedema may gradually worsen and get associated with the thickening of the skin and fibrosis of lymph vessels or blockage by adult worms. Hydrocele is another common manifestation that occurs due to lymphatic obstruction.

Microfilaria can be demonstrated in blood, chylous urine, exudate of lymph varix, and hydrocele fluid, however, peripheral blood is the preferred choice. The examination of a thick and thin blood smear stained with Giemsa stain shows the microfilaria. Other methods are by examining the unstained blood under a microscope for the actively motile microfilariae and by acridine orange-microhematocrit tube technique.

The best time to collect the blood samples is at night, between 10 pm and 4 am as they are nocturnally periodic.

DEC provocation test: In this test, a small dose of DEC is given 20-50 minutes before sample collection so that the microfilaria appears in the blood even during the daytime. 

The image below shows the life cycle of Wuchereria bancrofti.

*Note:

  • W.bancrofti causes Bancroftian filariasis and is transmitted by Culex quinquefasciatus (C. fatigans). In India, Wuchereria bancrofti is the commonest cause of filariasis.
  • B. malayi causes Burgian filariasis and the vector is the Mansonia mosquito.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to the casualty with a sudden loss of vision and painful ocular movements. On examination of the affected eye, a relative afferent pupillary defect with a normal optic disc is seen. Visual field testing was done which revealed central scotoma in the same eye. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a sudden painful loss of vision in the absence of fundoscopic changes, RAPD and central scotoma is suggestive of optic neuritis, specifically retrobulbar neuritis. 

There are 3 types of optic neuritis:

  • papillitis
  • neuroretinitis
  • retrobulbar neuritis

Clinically, optic neuritis is characterized by sudden, progressive visual loss.  Ocular movements are painful in retrobulbar neuritis and painless in papillitis and neuroretinitis. Glowing sensations known as phosphenes may be induced with sound or movement. Color vision may also be impaired. 

Signs of optic neuritis:

  • Marked reduction in visual acuity
  • Impaired color vision
  • Marcus Gunn Pupil indicates the relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD), is a diagnostic sign. Can be detected by swinging flashlight test
  • Disc hyperemia with blurred margin
  • Central or centrocaecal scotoma in the visual field (most common field defect in optic neuritis)

questions.text: As a medical officer posted in rural service, you have been asked to supervise the various preventive measures being taken in your region against malaria. According to the program whose logo is shown below, you would be correct to advise all of the following except:

choices.text: Two rounds of spraying with DDT should be done to provide protection during the entire transmission season.
Long Lasting Insecticide Nets (LLIN) should be provided in areas with Annual Parasite Index ≥ 5.
Indoor Residual Sprays are not suitable for vector control in rural areas.
In case of DDT resistance, 3 rounds of spraying with Malathion should be done to provide protection during the entire transmission season.

questions.solution:
Under the Integrated vector management initiative, Indoor Residual Sprays are the main methods of vector control in rural areas. 

National Vector Borne Disease Control Programme (NVBDCP) is the nodal agency for the prevention of control of the following vector-borne diseases:

  • Kala-azar (also called visceral leishmaniasis)
  • Malaria
  • Dengue
  • Filariasis
  • Japanese encephalitis
  • Chikungunya. 

Integrated Vector Management:

  • For adult mosquitoes:
    • Indoor residual Sprays are used. It is the main method of vector control in rural areas.
    • DDT is the insecticide of choice.
    • Two rounds of spraying are done with DDT and in DDT-resistant areas, three rounds of spraying are done with Malathion (if DDT-resistant).
  • For the larvae: Larvivorous fish and larvicides are used. This is the main method of vector control in urban areas.
  • For personal protection: 
    • Insecticide-treated bed nets are supplied in areas with Annual Parasite Index (API) ≥ 2.
    • Long-Lasting Insecticide Nets (LLIN) are provided in areas with API ≥ 5.

The Drug distribution centers only dispense anti-malarial drugs under the NVBDCP for Malaria. 

Important points about the organization for the anti-Malaria program:

  • Central Government: Supplies DDT and larvicides.
  • State government: Procures the Indoor Residual Sprays (IRS) for the districts.
  • District Malaria Office: Key unit for the implementation of the program.
  • District Malaria Officer: Has direct responsibility for IRS spraying operations and is assisted by one Assistant Malaria Officer and Malaria Inspectors. 
  • Medical officer of the PHC:  Has the overall responsibility for the surveillance and laboratory services.
  • Multi-Purpose Workers and ASHAs: Carry out surveillance and case detection in the community.
  • Drug Distribution Centres: Only dispensing anti-malarial drugs.
  • Fever Treatment Depots: Dispense the anti-malarial drugs and collect the blood slides.

Related Pearl: Insecticides

Contact poisons

  • Natural: Pyrethrum, rotenone, derris, nicotine, mineral oils
  • Synthetic:
    • Organo-chlorine compounds: DDT, methoxychlor, HCH, lindane, chlordane, heptachlor, dieldrin, aldrin, toxaphene, kepone, mirex.
    • Repellants: Benzyl benzoate, indalone, meta-diethyltoluamide, dimethyl phthalate, ethyl hexanediol.
    • Organo-phosphorus compounds: Chlorthion (aryl), diazinon (aryl), demethoate, malathion (alkyl), fenthion, parathion (aryl), trichlorfon (alkyl), runnel, abale, naled, chlorpyrifos, fenitrothion, dicapthon.
    • Carbamates: Carbaryl, dimetilan, propoxur, pyrolan.
    • Synthetic pyrethroids: Prothrin, resmethrin, bioresmethrin, permethrin, proparthin, tetramethrin
  • Stomach poisons: Paris green, sodium fluoride.
  • Fumigants: Hydrogen cyanide, methyl bromide, sulphur dioxide, carbon disulphide.
Specific Insecticides Comments
DDT (Dichloro-diphenyl-thrichloroethane) Insecticidal properties were discovered by Swiss scientist, Paul Muller. Most widely used insecticide. Attacks nerves of insects but doesn’t cause immediate death. White amorphous powder. Contains 70 – 80% of para-para isomers, which is the most active fraction of DDT. Has residual action up to 18 months. Used as a residual spray.Least toxic organo-chlorine compound.
HCH (hexachlorocyclo-hexane) Synthesized by Michael Faraday. Normal HCH contains 13 – 16% of gamma isomer. Gamma-HCH or lindane has 99% gamma isomer.Short residual action – 3 months.
Malathion Least toxicity of all organophosphorus compounds. Used as an ultra-low volume spray.
Fenthion Also called baytex. Used as a residual spray.
Pyrethrum Vegetable origin – Chrysanthemum cinerariafolium. Nerve poison and is excellent as a space spray.No residual action.Synergistic action with DDT as space spray.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding antigenic drift?

choices.text: There is a gradual sequential change in antigenic structure
It doesn’t account for the periodic epidemics of influenza
The new antigens thus formed are totally unrelated to the previous antigens
Antibodies to the predecessor viruses do not neutralise the new variants

questions.solution:
Antigenic drift causes a gradual sequential change in antigenic structure.

Antigenic variation is a property of influenza viruses by which it alters the antigenic structure on its surface and thus avoids a host immune response. It is of two types - Antigenic shift and antigenic drift.

Influenza vaccine requires periodic strain change due to antigenic change in the surface glycoprotein of the virus.

questions.text: A 14-year-old male has been diagnosed with a condition due to a DNA repair gene defect. He is having hyperpigmentation on the skin and is said to be at a high risk for the development of skin cancers by his physician. Which of the following mechanisms is likely to be defective in this condition?
questions.solution:
The above given clinical findings are suggestive of xeroderma pigmentosum. Xeroderma pigmentosum is an example of defective DNA nucleotide excision repair.

Xeroderma Pigmentosum (XP) is a rare autosomal recessive genetic disorder characterized by defective DNA repair which leads to clinical and cellular hypersensitivity to ultraviolet (UV) radiation.

UV radiation leads to pyrimidine dimerization in DNA strands, preventing further replication by DNA polymerase. The nucleotide excision repair mechanism corrects the dimer formation in DNA. In XP there is an inability to repair DNA pyrimidine dimers caused by UV exposure.

In XP the skin is normal at birth. Initially, there will be diffuse erythema, scaling, and freckle lesions. As age progresses a characterized lesion called poikiloderma occurs. It consists of skin atrophy, telangiectasia, and mottled hyper and hypopigmented areas. By the age of 4 -5 years, they present with multiple malignancies including squamous cell carcinoma, malignant melanoma, basal cell carcinoma, and fibrosarcoma.

Most of the cases with XP have ocular manifestations. Initially, it appears as photophobia, conjunctivitis, ectropion, and symblepharon with ulceration. Accumulation of pyrimidine dimer causes corneal opacification and neovascularization. Ocular malignancies are common in the lids, conjunctiva, and cornea as they are exposed to as much as facial skin.

XP is ultimately fatal, and early detection of the skin lesions and their management with prevention of UV rays exposures prolong the life.

questions.text: In the cardiac muscle, the inhibition of Na+K+ATPase results in __?
questions.solution:
The inhibition of Na+K+-ATPase results in depolarisation.

An energy (ATP)-dependent pump system (Na+/K+-ATPase), is located on the sarcolemma, which pumps Na+ out and K+ into the cell.The Na+/K+-ATPase pump is electrogenic because it extrudes three Na+ for every two K+ entering the cell. By pumping more positive charges out of the cell than into it, the pump creates a negative potential within the cell. This electrogenic potential may be up to −10 mV.

If this pump stops working (such as when ATP is lost under hypoxic conditions), or if the activity of the pump is inhibited by cardiac glycosides such as digoxin, Na+ accumulates within the cell and intracellular K+ falls,resulting in a less negative (more depolarized) resting membrane potential.

Inhibition of this pump, therefore, causes depolarization resulting from changes in Na+ and K+ concentration gradients and from the loss of an electrogenic component of the membrane potential.

Action potential of myocardium:

  • Phase 0: Depolarisation: Influx of Na+ into myocyte.
  • Phase 1: Early repolarization: Efflux of K+ from myocyte.
  • Phase 2: Plateau: Ca2+ enters myocardial cells via voltage regulated L-type Ca2+ channels.
  • Phase 3: Repolarisation: Efflux of K+.
  • Phase 4: Restoration of RMP: Restoration of Na+ and K+ by Na-K ATPase.

questions.text: A 70-year-old patient with a history of schizophrenia, and on treatment for drug-induced Parkinson's presents with complaints of constipation, blurred vision, and dry mouth. Which of the following drugs may be responsible for the above symptoms?

The given clinical scenario of a patient with Schizophrenia and on treatment for drug-induced Parkinson's disease is suggestive of the patient being treated with benzhexol (trihexyphenidyl). Benzhexol is the drug of choice for drug-induced Parkinson's disease. The side effects of benzhexol include anticholinergic symptoms such as constipation, blurred vision, and dry mouth (xerostomia).

Drug-induced Parkinsonism is a condition that is caused by certain drugs that have D2 antagonistic action like typical antipsychotics. Due to the decrease in dopaminergic activity, they result in an unbalanced cholinergic activity. Benzhexol is a centrally-acting antimuscarinic agent. questions.text: Identify this  movement that takes place in the intestine?
questions.solution:
The given image is of peristalsis.

Peristalsis is a propulsive movement in the GI tract, starting in the esophagus and ending in the rectum. It follows the law of gut- forward directed towards the rectum, because of the intact myenteric plexus.

It begins with the local stretch produced by the food and the wave of contraction propels forward at 2-25cm/s speed. It is independent of external innervation, but autonomic activity may increase or decrease the activity.

The interstitial cells of Cajal, act as pacemakers of the GI tract, They maintain a basal electric rhythm (BER). It doesn’t cause contraction on its own but maintains muscle tension. Its function is to coordinate the various motility of the GI tract. For example, in the absence of BER, peristalsis waves in the stomach will be irregular and chaotic.

Regulation- sustains by self, autonomic system, and the interstitial cells of cajal fine tune it.

questions.text: In a  case of drowning, the following finding is seen at autopsy. What is it called?
questions.solution:
The image shown above represents a firm hand grip on weeds and mud, found in a victim of drowning. It is indicative of the last action performed by the victim. This is an example of a cadaveric spasm.

Cadaveric spasm/Instantaneous rigor/cataleptic rigidity/death clutch:

  • It is a phenomenon where a group of muscles that are in a state of contraction at the time of death remains contracted after death till molecular death occurs.
  • It occurs immediately after death. There is no stage of primary relaxation.
  • It is seen in cases of deaths coupled with emotional disturbances like in case of excitement, fear, severe pain, exhaustion at the time of death, cerebral hemorrhage, injury to the nervous system, drowning, strychnine poisoning.
  • It is an ante mortem phenomenon and it indicates the manner of death and not the time since death.

Other options:

Option B: Cutis anserina (goose-skin or goose-flesh), in which the skin has a granular and puckered appearance can be seen on the anterior surfaces of the body, especially on the thighs.  It is produced by the spasm of the erector pilae muscles, attached to each hair follicle, and can occur in the living when the skin comes in contact with cold water. It can occur on submersion of the body in cold water immediately after death, while the muscles were still warm and irritable. It can also be produced by rigor mortis of the erector muscles.

Option C: Rigor mortis is a postmortem phenomenon indicative of molecular death. It is useful in estimating the time since death. The mechanism of rigor mortis is due to muscle ATP breakdown below the critical level.  It appears 2-3 hours after death and is usually preceded by postmortem flaccidity. It involves both the voluntary and involuntary muscles of the body and persists for about 12-24 hours. 

Option D: Washerwoman’s hands is a specific change that is seen in the skin of the palm and sole, which comprises of wrinkled, swollen, whitish sodden appearance of hands or feet. It can also be considered as water maceration of skin of the hand, due to absorption of water into the outer layers of skin. Though the washerwomen’s hand and feet changes are usually seen in dead bodies recovered from water, this cannot be considered as a sign of antemortem drowning.

questions.text: Potassium is maximally absorbed in____
questions.solution:

Potassium is freely filtered by the glomerulus. The bulk of filtered K+ is reabsorbed in the proximal tubule. In the proximal tubule, K+ absorption is primarily passive and proportional to Na+ and water through paracellular transport. 

K+ reabsorption in the thick ascending limb of Henle occurs through both transcellular (Na+- K+- 2Cl- cotransport) and paracellular pathways.

K+ secretion begins in the early distal convoluted tubule and progressively increases along the distal nephron into the cortical collecting duct. Most urinary K+ can be accounted for by K+ secretion mediated by principal cells. Under conditions of K+ depletion, reabsorption of K+ occurs in the collecting duct. 

It is the only electrolyte to be reabsorbed as well as secreted.

questions.text: Identify the class of immunoglobulin​ shown in the image below.
questions.solution:
The above image shows a dimeric structure, characteristic of secretory IgA.

IgA immunoglobulin is the major antibody responsible for mucosal immunity. Its serum levels are usually low. It is predominantly present in the extravascular secretions. It is present in secretions such as milk, saliva, and tears, and in secretions of the respiratory, intestinal, and genital tracts.

When present in the serum, it exists as a monomer similar to IgG. However, when it is secreted, it exists as a dimer. The dimeric structure consists of two monomers, which are stabilized by two additional polypeptides:

Chaperones assist in protein folding. They are a type of heat-shock protein weighing 70 kDa (hsp70).

Mechanism of action:

questions.text: A 64-year-old woman was brought by her son, during a cataract outreach camp.  She gives a history of trauma to her left eye, one year back and a complete loss of vision in that eye since then. Her left eye image is given below. What is the next line of management ?
questions.solution:
The above clinical vignette and image showing a dense white opacity, and scarring of more than half of the stroma is characteristic of leucomatous corneal opacity and the treatment of choice is keratoplasty.

Corneal opacities can be graded, depending on their density, as:

  • Nebular corneal opacities or nebula, where only slight opacification of the cornea occurs due to scarring. It is possible to observe the iris clearly through this type of opacity.
  • Macular corneal opacities or macula, which is described as a semi-dense opacity that can be seen with proper illumination. This occurs subsequent to scarring that spans about half the corneal stroma. The iris and pupillary margins are usually visible.
  • Leucomatous corneal opacities or leucoma simplex, which is a white scar that is easily seen just by looking at the eye. It occurs due to scarring of more than half of the corneal stroma.
  • Adherent leucoma is observed when there is perforation and subsequent healing of the cornea, but with the incarceration of the iris in it.

Secondary changes in corneal opacity which may be seen in long-standing cases include hyaline degeneration, calcareous degeneration, pigmentation and atheromatous ulceration.

The treatment depends upon the type of opacity. Keratoplasty is the treatment of choice in leucomatous corneal opacities. Optical iridectomy may be performed in cases with central adherent leucomas. Phototherapeutic keratectomy (PTK) performed with excimer laser is useful only in superficial (nebular) corneal opacities.

Corneal tattooing is a treatment option in patients with corneal opacities with firm scarring and poor vision. It only improves cosmetic appearance.

questions.text: If the diameter of an artery was found to be reduced to one-third. By what value does the resistance of the artery increase?
questions.solution:
The resistance increases by 81 times.

The relationship between the flow in a long narrow tube, the viscosity of the fluid, and the radius of the tube is expressed by the Poiseuille-Hagen formula.

Vessel resistance (R) is therefore inversely proportional to the radius to the fourth power (r4).

In the given question, the diameter is reduced to one-third. So, the radius is also reduced to one-third. Hence, vessel resistance will increase by 34 or 81 times.

questions.text: An elderly diabetic female patient presented with a black, foul-smelling discharge from the nose. On examination, a blackish necrotic mass filled the nasal cavity and eroded the septum and hard palate. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Mucormycosis.

Diabetic patients with local tissue destruction with blackish nasal discharge typically resembles the presentation of invasive mucormycosis. The blackish discolouration is due to direct fungal invasion causing arterial and venous thrombosis leading to gangrene. Mucormycosis is an opportunistic infection caused principally by species of Rhizopus, Mucor, and Lichtheimia. The most prevalent species is Rhizopus Oryza. 

Risk factors:

  • Diabetes (diabetic ketoacidosis).
  • Immunocompromised individuals

Treatment:

  • Intravenous administration of amphotericin B is the treatment of choice for invasive mucormycosis.
  • Surgical debridement
  • Control of underlying predisposing causes.

Other options:

Option A: Invasive aspergillosis leads to the formation of black or greyish membrane in the nasal mucosa. The maxillary sinus may contain a fungus ball containing semisolid cheesy-white or blackish material.

Option C: Foreign body nose presents with foul-smelling unilateral discharge.

Option D: Rhinosporidiosis is a granulomatous condition caused by Rhinosporidium seeberi and presents with nasal discharge, epistaxis, and nasal obstruction by a polypoidal mass.

questions.text: A 36-year-old man complained of bluish-black discoloration of sclera and pinna for the last 6 months. Since childhood, his urine has turned black on standing as shown in the image below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical features along with the blackening of urine on standing are characteristic of alkaptonuria.

Alkaptonuria is an autosomal recessive disorder of tyrosine metabolism, that develops due to the defect in homogentisate oxidase/ homogentisic acid 1, 2 - dioxygenase, which oxidizes homogentisate to maleylacetoacetate. The defect in this enzyme leads to the accumulation of homogentisate, which is then excreted in the urine. 

Alkaptonuria is characterized by homogentisic aciduria, ochronosis, and arthropathy (joint pain).

Homogentisic aciduria is the black discoloration of urine on prolonged exposure to air caused due to oxidation of the excreted homogentisate. 

Ochronosis, which is bluish-black pigmentation in connective tissue; generally occurs after the third decade of life and it occurs due to the accumulation of homogentisic acid and its oxidation products like benzoquinone acetic acid in connective tissue.

Arthritis generally begins in the third decade. Arthritis often begins in the spine and resembles ankylosing spondylitis in its large-joint distribution. Radiographs of the spine showing flattened and calcified intervertebral discs are pathognomonic. Other findings include degeneration of the intervertebral discs followed by disc calcification and eventually fusion of the vertebral bodies. Osteophyte formation and calcification of the intervertebral ligaments also occur.

Diagnosis: Blackish discoloration of urine on standing is diagnostic of alkaptonuria. The ferric chloride test will be positive.

The images below show pigmentation of the skin and an x-ray of the spine that shows calcification of intervertebral discs.

questions.text: A mother noticed a mucopurulent discharge from the right puncta of her 3-month-old child. There is a history of increased watering in his right eye. Which of the following is the appropriate treatment?
questions.solution:
The above history of epiphora (increased watering) and mucopurulent discharge from the punctum is suggestive of congenital dacryocystitis.

Congenital dacrocystitis is the chronic inflammation of the lacrimal sac. It occurs due to the stasis of secretions which in turn is due to congenital blockage of the nasolacrimal duct.

Regurgitation test (applying pressure over the lacrimal sac causes regurgitation of mucopurulent discharge from the lower punctum) is usually positive.

More than 90% of patients with congenital nasolacrimal obstruction undergo spontaneous resolution by 1 year of age.

Treatment depends on the age of the child:

  • Less than 9 months
    • Massaging (Crigler’s massage, which increases the hydrostatic pressure)
    • Antibiotics eye drops
  • 9 months to 4 years
    • Probing
  • Older children (> 4 years):
    • Dacryocystorhinostomy (DCR)
    • In DCR, an opening is made into the nasal cavity from the lacrimal sac.
    • DCR gives the best result.

questions.text: You are working as an internal medicine consultant at a private clinic. A patient with chronic renal disease requiring hemodialysis is admitted under you. You advise diet and fluid control and keep him under observation. However, the patient progresses to take ayurvedic supplements and sometimes skips the your instructions without disclosing it. His conditions worsen and he develops difficulty in breathing. His attendant files a complaint in court alleging the negligence of the doctor. Which of the following acts as a defence for the doctor in court?
questions.solution:
In the given case, since the patient did not adhere to the proper instructions of the doctor, it was partly or wholly his fault. This is termed contributory negligence. Proper documentation as to how ordinary care was not exercised on part of the patient can be useful in a court of law.

Contributory negligence occurs when a patient or his personal attendant shows unreasonable conduct or absence of ordinary care, which when combined with the negligence of the doctor, has contributed to the injury. In this case, the patient’s or attendant’s negligence should be the direct, proximate cause and without which the injury would not have occurred

Other options:

Option A: Vicarious liability is not a defense against professional negligence. Vicarious liability (liability for the actions of another): An employer is responsible not only for his own negligence but also for the negligence of his employees.

Option B: Res ipsa loquitur means 'the thing speaks for itself'. It is used as supportive evidence of negligence on part of the doctor eg: leaving behind a scalpel or scissor whilst operating leading to sepsis/peritonitis speaks for itself.

Option C: Therapeutic misadventure may serve as a defense against negligence. It basically refers to an adverse outcome that could not have been anticipated despite reasonable care. eg: a rare side effect of a drug or blood loss due to an anomalous artery despite exercising caution.

Related Pearl: Contributory negligence

Contributory negligence occurs when a patient or his personal attendant shows unreasonable conduct or absence of ordinary care, which when combined with the negligence of the doctor, has contributed to the injury. In this case, the patient’s or attendant’s negligence should be the direct, proximate cause and without which the injury would not have occurred.

So, contributory negligence occurs when both the doctor and patient are negligent. The direct or proximate cause of the injury should be the patient’s negligence, which means that if the patient was not negligent, the injury could have been prevented.

Contributory negligence usually occurs when the doctor is negligent and the patient:

  • Fails to give an accurate medical history, and as a result, the doctor may misdiagnose or mistreat the patient.
  • Fails to follow the doctor’s instructions
  • Refuses to take the treatment
  • Leaves the hospital against doctor’s advice
  • Does not inform the doctor or seek further medical assistance if the symptoms persist or worsens.

Contributory negligence is a defence for doctor’s negligence in civil cases. However, from case to case, the liability of a doctor may vary from complete non-liability to substantial liability for the damages. Under the doctrine of comparative negligence, the court has the right to hold both parties liable for their negligent actions.

Limitations / Exceptions to contributory negligence:

A. The doctor will be held guilty in the following conditions:

1. The doctor failed to provide proper instructions to the patient

  • Ex: Doctor applies a tight plaster cast (doctor is negligent) to the patient’s leg and did not tell the patient to inform if he develops any numbness (no proper instruction). The patient develops numbness and has not informed the doctor (patient is negligent). After few days patient developed a permanent injury.

 2. Last clear chance doctrine: It is applicable when the doctor fails to take necessary action to prevent damage due to a negligent act of the patient, even after getting a clear chance to take such action.

  • Ex: Doctor applies a tight plaster cast (doctor is negligent) to the patient’s leg and told the patient to inform if he develops any numbness (gave proper instruction). The patient developed numbness and has not informed the doctor (patient is negligent). Next day patient informed the doctor, but the doctor did not remove the cast and said he was busy (There was a clear last chance, but the doctor neglected again). After few days patient developed a permanent injury.

B. The doctor/person will not be held guilty in the following conditions:

1. Avoidable consequences rule: It occurs when an injury is caused due to doctor’s negligence, and the patient has done a negligent act, which further aggravated the injury caused by the doctor, and the patient could have avoided the consequence by not doing such act. In such cases, the doctor need not pay anything, and the patient will be held guilty.

  • Ex: A patient had a lacerated wound. The doctor examined the patient and had not done any dressing or provided any antibiotics (the doctor is negligent). However, the doctor instructed the patient to avoid contamination and asked him to visit the clinic next week. When the patient went home, he applied cow dung on his wound every day thinking that the wound would heal faster and didn't visit the doctor after one week. The wound got infected and developed pus and aggravated the injury.
  • Here, despite the doctor being negligent in the first instance, the patient is responsible for his injury as he performed an unnecessary, avoidable act, which aggravated the injury. The doctor need not pay anything.

2. Good Samaritan doctrine: A person who assists another person who is in serious danger cannot be charged with contributory negligence. unless such assistance is reckless or rash.

  • Ex: A person was travelling on a road and saw a car accident, where the victim was unconscious and was stuck inside the car. He called the ambulance. The paramedical staff instructed him not to mobilize the victim until they arrived. Meanwhile, the car was caught in fire (serious danger), and the person tried to remove the victim carefully out of the car (assisted the victim and was not reckless). However, the victim already had a cervical bone fracture due to the accident, which got mobilized while he was being removed out of the car and as a result, suffered an injury to the spine that led to paralysis (victim’s injury was aggravated). In such a case, the good samaritan doctrine would apply and the person who tried to help, will not be charged under contributory negligence.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy was brought to the ophthalmology OPD with complaints of intense itching, photophobia, and ropy discharge from his eyes. Moreover, on examination the following finding is present. What is the most probable diagnosis of this patient?
questions.solution:
The above image depicts a cobblestone appearance, and also the presence of ropy discharge points towards the diagnosis of vernal keratoconjunctivitis (VKC) or spring catarrh.

VKC is bilateral allergic conjunctivitis that is common in children above the age of 5 years and in warm dry climates such as the Mediterranean, sub-Saharan Africa, and the Middle East.

It is IgE and cell-mediated inflammation of the conjunctiva. It results in the following findings:

Palpebral disease

  • Cobblestone papillae: Macropapillae (<1 mm) have a flat-topped polygonal appearance reminiscent of cobblestones
  • Associated with ropy discharge
  • Maxwell–Lyon sign: pseudomembrane formation of the upper lid when everted and exposed to heat 

Limbal disease

  • Horner-Trantas dots which are limbal conjunctival papillae

Keratopathy

  • Superior punctate epithelial erosions
  • Shield ulcers, which may develop when the exposed Bowman membrane becomes coated with mucus and calcium phosphate, leading to inadequate wetting and delayed re-epithelialization.
  • Pseudogerentexon resembling arcus senilus. It has a cupid's bow outline

Treatment of VKC includes allergen avoidance, antihistaminics, steroids, and immunomodulators both topical and systemic depending on the severity of the disease.

questions.text: Which of the following describes Haldane effect?

choices.text: Binding of O2 to Hb favours release of CO2
Binding of CO2 to Hb favours release of O2
HCO3- leaving RBC in exchange for Cl-

questions.solution:
Binding of O2 with hemoglobin tends to displace CO2 from the blood. This effect is called the Haldane effect. 

Haldane effect:

  • Binding of O2 with hemoglobin tends to displace CO2 from the blood. This effect, called the Haldane effect, is important in promoting CO2 transport.
  • The Haldane effect results from the simple fact that the combination of O2 with hemoglobin in the lungs causes the hemoglobin to become a stronger acid. This displaces CO2 from the blood and into the alveoli.

(Remember - HaLdane effect occurs in Lungs and causes Left shift of O2-Hb dissociation curve).

Some other effects:

Bohr effect: A shift of the oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve to the right in response to increases in blood CO2 and hydrogen ions, has a significant effect by enhancing the release of O2 from the blood in the tissues and enhancing oxygenation of the blood in the lungs.

Chloride shift:

  • Upon entering the red blood cell, CO2 is rapidly hydrated to H2CO3 by carbonic anhydrase.
  • H2CO3 is in equilibrium with H+ and its conjugate base, HCO3-.
  • H+ can interact with deoxyhemoglobin, whereas HCO3- can be transported outside of the cell via anion exchanger 1 (AE1 or Band 3).
  • In effect, for each CO2 molecule that enters the red cell, there is an additional HCO3- or Cl- in the cell.
  • Because of this chloride shift, the Cl – content of the red cells in venous blood is significantly greater than that in arterial blood.
  • Note that for each CO2 molecule added to a red cell, there is an increase of one osmotically active particles in the cell - either a HCO 3 – or a Cl – ion. Consequently, the red cells take up water and increase in size.

Causes of the right shift of the oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve:

  • Hypoxia and Hypercarbia - metabolically active tissues utilize O2 and tissues produce CO2
  • ↓ pH - Secondary to increased CO2 production
  • ↑ in temperature
  • ↑ in 2,3-DPG - increased anaerobic glycolysis
  • Growth hormone, thyroid hormone, androgen - by increasing 2,3 DPG
  • Sickle cell anemia - reduced affinity for O2
  • Exercise

Causes of the left shift of oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve:

  • ↑ pH (alkalosis)
  • ↓ PCO2
  • ↓ 2,3-DPG
  • ↓ Temperature 
  • HbF

questions.text: A 21-year-old chronic alcoholic is brought to the emergency room with confusion and tremors. On examination, there is ataxia and ophthalmoplegia. Deficiency of which of the following is responsible for the condition?
questions.solution:
This patient's clinical features are suggestive of Wernicke's encephalopathy. It is seen due to the deficiency of thiamine/vitamin B1.

Wernicke's encephalopathy/alcoholic encephalopathy is an acute neurological disorder. Glucose infusions may precipitate Wernicke’s disease in a previously unaffected patient or cause a rapid worsening of an early form of the disease (as in this patient). For this reason, thiamine should be administered to all alcoholic patients requiring parenteral glucose.

The triad is (mnemonic - GOA):

  • Global Confusion
  • Ophthalmoplegia (first symptom to improve with thiamine +dextrose infusion)
  • Ataxia

Alcohol abuse leads to thiamine deficiency by the following mechanisms:

  • Poor nutritional habits
  • Folate deficiency which reduces thiamine absorption from the gastrointestinal tract
  • Direct damage of the intestinal mucosa

The initial treatment in a patient with Wernicke's disease should be emergent thiamine infusion, either IM or IV. This should be given daily until a normal diet is resumed and before treatment with IV glucose. Administration of glucose before thiamine can worsen Wernicke's encephalopathy.

questions.text: Which of the following is part of trotter's triad, seen in nasopharyngeal carcinoma?

choices.text: Conductive hearing loss, ipsilateral temporoparietal neuralgia, palatal paralysis
