questions.solution:
Trotter’s triad seen in nasopharyngeal carcinoma consists of conductive hearing loss, ipsilateral temporoparietal neuralgia, and palatal paralysis.

In nasopharyngeal carcinoma, the tumour's location near these cranial nerves can lead to their compression or infiltration, resulting in the characteristic symptoms of Trotter's triad. Therefore, cranial nerves V (trigeminal nerve) and X (vagus nerve) are commonly affected in this condition.

Nasopharyngeal carcinoma, a malignancy arising from the nasopharynx, can manifest with Trotter's triad, which includes:

  • Conductive deafness: This occurs due to obstruction or dysfunction of the eustachian tube, leading to impaired middle ear function.
  • Ipsilateral temporoparietal neuralgia: This symptom is characterized by sharp, shooting pain in the temporoparietal region of the head. It is primarily caused by the involvement of the trigeminal nerve (cranial nerve V), which carries sensory fibres from the face and certain parts of the head.
  • Palatal paralysis: This condition results from the involvement of the vagus nerve (cranial nerve X), which innervates the muscles of the soft palate. Palatal paralysis can lead to difficulty in swallowing, nasal regurgitation of fluids, and a nasal voice quality

questions.text: A 5-year-old child with a ​history of perianal pain is brought to the OPD. On subjecting the specimen from the perianal region to a test, it produces yellow rhombic crystals of spermine picrate. What is the test done?
questions.solution:
The test done in the scenario is Barberio test. It is used to detect seminal fluid.

When saturated aqueous or alcoholic solution of picric acid is added to the spermatic fluid, yellow needle-shaped rhombic crystals of spermine picrate are produced.

Other options: 

Option B: Florence test: 

  • The suspected seminal stain is extracted with 10% hydrochloric acid and a drop of it is placed over a slide.
  • A coverslip is placed over it and a drop of Florence solution (potassium iodide, iodine, and water) is made to run under the coverslip.
  • If semen is present, dark brown rhombic or needle-shaped crystals of choline iodide appear immediately.

Option C: Takayama test (Haemochromogen crystal test): 

  • The test is used to detect suspected bloodstains. Small piece of suspected material is added on a glass slide.
  • Then, 2-3 drops of Takayama reagent is added and covered with a coverslip.
  • If it is a bloodstain, pink feathery crystals of hemochromogen or reduced alkaline haematin appear in a few minutes.

Option D: Teichmann test (Haemin Crystal Test): 

  • The test is used to detect suspected bloodstains.
  • Small piece of suspected material is placed on a glass slide. Then, 2-3 drops of glacial acetic acid and a small crystal of sodium chloride are added to the glass slide and covered with a coverslip. The slide is then heated.
  • If bloodstain is present, faint yellowish-red to brownish-black rhombic crystals of haemin or haematin chloride appear.
  • When hydrogen peroxide is added, the haematin crystals give bubbles of gas.

questions.text: A patient chronically on corticosteroids was diagnosed with a complicated cataract. His slit lamp examination finding is shown below. What is this type of cataract called?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of chronic use of steroids along with slit lamp examination showing a granular appearance in the lens is suggestive of posterior subcapsular cataract.

Posterior subcapsular opacity lies in front of the posterior capsule and has a granular or plaque-like appearance on oblique slit lamp examination .On retro- illumination , black vacuoles are seen which are swollen migratory lens epithelial cells called as Wedl cells (or bladder cells). As it is in the centre of the eye it has a significant impact on vision. Symptoms like glare are often perceived and aggravated by miosis , near visual activity and in bright light. 

The following conditions mainly present with a posterior subcapsular cataract and therefore have a similar clinical picture:

  • Complicated cataract
  • Steroid-induced cataract
  • Radiation

 These cataracts present with central opacities and has difficulty in seeing objects in bright light because:

  • When a person is exposed to bright light, the pupil undergoes miosis (constriction).
  • These central opacities come to lie directly in the path of axial rays, allowing no transmission of rays.
  • Therefore, there is an inability to see objects in bright light.
  • However, in dim light, when there is mydriasis (dilatation of pupil), some rays may pass around the opacity, leading to an improvement in dim-light vision.

questions.text: A 60-year-old diabetic male presents with a history of decreased vision. Fluorescein angiography showed the following image. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image of fundus fluorescein angiography (FFA) depicts neovascularization, which is the hallmark of proliferative diabetic retinopathy.

The neovascularization arises from the optic nerve head; there is neovascularization of the disc (NVD) along the large vessels and neovascularization elsewhere (NVE).

The treatment available for proliferative diabetic retinopathy is photocoagulation of the ischaemic areas to reduce the metabolic demand and decrease or prevent the release of vasoproliferative factors.

  • Intra-retinal microvascular abnormalities
  • Venous changes (such as beading)
  • Cotton wool spots
  • Deep retinal hemorrhages

Proliferative Diabetic Retinopathy:

  • NeoVascularization of the optic Disc (NVD)
  • NeoVascularization Elsewhere in the periphery of the fundus (NVE)

Advanced Diabetic Eye Disease:

  • Tractional retinal detachment
  • Vitreous hemorrhage
  • Neovascular glaucoma

Diabetic Maculopathy is a separate entity that is applied to the changes that occur in the macula such as macular edema or ischemia.

Cotton wool spots (old name soft exudates) appear as whitish fluffy spots with indistinct margins. These represent areas of nerve fiber infarcts. Common causes are hypertensive retinopathy, toxaemic retinopathy of pregnancy, diabetic retinopathy, anemias, and collagen disorders like discoid lupus erythematosus, polyarteritis nodosa, and scleroderma.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about BERA (Brainstem Evoked Response Audiometry)?

choices.text: It can be used for screening of conductive hearing loss

  • Click stimulus is used
  • Responses are not frequency specific

    • Differentiating cochlear and retro-cochlear hearing loss
    • Diagnosing non-organic hearing loss.

  • Used to elicit brainstem responses to auditory stimulation by clicks or tone bursts.
  • Non-invasive technique to find the integrity of central auditory pathways through the eighth nerve, pons and midbrain.

A transoral endoscopic approach (Dohlman's procedure) -using staplers, laser, or coagulation through an endoscope that ablate the septum between the diverticulum and the cervical esophagus, can be used for diverticula between 2 and 5 cm in size.

The treatment is either endoscopic or open surgery.For diverticula 3 cm or smaller in size, surgical repair is superior and thus preferred to endoscopic repair.

Zenker's diverticulum occurs due to herniation of mucosa and submucosa through the Killian's triangle, which is a weak area between two parts of the inferior constrictor - (thyropharyngeus and cricopharyngeus) in the posterior pharyngeal wall. It is usually seen in elderly patients (>60 years).

  • Acquired

  • Regurgitation
  • Halitosis
  • Aspiration

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy is brought to the OPD with complaints of fever, ear pain, and difficulty in swallowing for 1 week. On examination, there is testicular swelling and his jaw is as shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with fever, ear pain, parotid swelling, and testicular swelling is suggestive of mumps.

Mumps is caused by RNA paramyxovirus. It is spread from person to person via droplets from clinical and subclinical cases. The incubation period is 12-21 days. The virus appears in the saliva from up to 7 days before to as long as 7 days after the onset of parotid swelling.

The patient presents with prodrome lasting 1-2 days consisting of fever, headache, and vomiting. After the prodrome, unilateral or bilateral parotitis develops, which is tender. It may be associated with ipsilateral ear pain. Ingestion of sour or acidic foods may enhance pain.

It can be prevented by administering live attenuated, MMR vaccine at 15-18 months and 5 years.

Complications of mumps:

  • Aseptic meningitis or meningoencephalitis
  • Epididymo-orchitis which is usually unilateral. Seen in post-pubertal males
  • Oophoritis
  • Other complications include pancreatitis and myocarditis

Meningoencephalitis/aseptic meningitis can occur before, along with, or after parotitis. Most commonly, it manifests 5 days after parotitis. It can present with headaches, neck stiffness, and drowsiness.

*Note: Non-mumps parotitis can be caused by:

  • Epstein-Barr virus - causes infectious mononucleosis
  • Coxsackievirus - causes herpangina
  • Parainfluenza virus - causes croup

questions.text: A man was found dead due to starvation.Which of the following findings will be seen on autopsy?
questions.solution:
In starvation, the gall bladder is distended.

In starvation, bile does not get secreted into the duodenum due to the absence of food entering the stomach and intestine. So bile gets accumulated in the gall bladder and gets distended.

Starvation:

  • The feeling of intense hunger lasts for 30–48 hours.
  • A person can survive for 10–12 days without food and water and for 6–8 weeks without food alone.
  • Loss of 40% of body weight is usually fatal.
  • Loss of 70–90% of body fat and 20% of body protein is fatal.
  • There is a reduction in the weight and size of all organs except the brain.

Other features of starvation:

  • Dry, lustreless hair
  • Brittle nails 
  • Pale skin with edema around ankles
  • Loss of fat in subcutaneous tissue, in the omentum 
    (sparing of fat in female breast and orbit till later)
  • Atrophy of muscles and darkening due to lipochrome
  • The heart is atrophied with empty chambers
  • Pale and collapsed lung
  • Shrunken liver with necrosis
  • Tissue paper-like intestinal mucosa
  • Empty bladder

questions.text: A 35 year old male presented to the clinic with complaints of  episodic vertigo,  sense of ear pressure and fullness, decreased hearing, and a low-tone roaring tinnitus. What is the possible clinical diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis is that of Meniere's disease. It is also called endolymphatic hydrops.

Pathology:
The primary pathology in Ménière’s disease is the distension of the endolymphatic system due to an increased endolymph volume. This can result either from increased production of endolymph or its faulty absorption or both. Normally, endolymph is secreted by stria vascularis, fills the membranous labyrinth, and is absorbed through the endolymphatic sac.

Clinical features:

Accordingly, the typical history involves episodic attacks of true whirling vertigo, which usually are preceded by a variable sense of ear pressure and fullness, decreased hearing, and low-tone roaring tinnitus. 

Examination:

  • Otoscopy - No abnormality seen in the tympanic membrane.
  • Nystagmus - Seen only during an acute attack. The quick component of nystagmus is towards the unaffected ear.
  • Tuning fork test - Indicate sensorineural hearing loss. Rinne's test is positive, Weber is lateralized to the better ear. Absolute bone conduction is reduced in the affected ear.

Investigations:

i) Pure Tone Audiometry (PTA): sensorineural hearing loss is present.  
ii) Speech audiometry: Discrimination score is usually 55 - 85% between the attacks but discrimination ability is much impaired during and immediately following the attacks.

iii) Special audiometry test :

  • Recruitment is positive.
  • SISI score is better than 70% in 2/3rds patients.
  • Tone decay test - decay of less than 20dB.

iv) Electrocochleography: It shows changes diagnostic of Ménière's disease. SP/ AP ratio is greater than 30%.

v) Caloric test: It shows reduced response on the affected side in 75% of cases.

vi) Glycerol test: Glycerol is a dehydrating agent. When given orally, it reduces endolymph pressure.

Diagnosis of Meniere's disease : 

Committee on Hearing and Equilibrium of the American Academy of Otorhinolaryngology-Head and Neck Surgery (AAOHNS) classified the diagnosis of Ménière's disease as follows:

Certain: Definite Ménière's disease confirmed by histopathology. 
Definite: Two or more final spontaneous episodes of vertigo lasting 20 minutes or longer.

                a) Audiometrically documented hearing loss on at least one occasion.

                b) Tinnitus or aural fullness in the affected ear.

                c) All other causes excluded.

Probable: 

                a) One definitive episode of vertigo.

                b) Audiometrically documented hearing loss on at least one occasion.

                c) Tinnitus or aural fullness in the treated ear.

                d) Other causes excluded.

Possible:

                a) Episodic vertigo of Ménière's type without documented hearing loss ( vestibular variant) or

                b) Sensorineural hearing loss, fluctuating or fixed, with disequilibrium but without definitive episodes (cochlear variant).

                c) Other causes excluded.

Treatment: 

A)  General measures:

  • Reassurance
  • Cessation of smoking
  • Low salt diet
  • Avoid excessive intake of water
  • Avoid over-indulgence in tea/ coffee/ alcohol.
  • Avoid stress and bring a change in lifestyle
  • Avoid activities requiring good body balance

B) Management in the acute phase:

  • Reassurance
  • Bed rest
  • Vestibular sedatives - Promethazine theoclate , Prochlorperazine , Dimenhydrinate
  • Vasodilators - Inhalation of carbogen, Histamine drip, etc.,

C) Management in the chronic phase:

  • Vestibular sedatives - Prochlorperazine
  • Vasodilators - Nicotinic acid, Betahistine,etc.,
  • Diuretics - Furosemide
  • Propantheline bromide 
  • Elimination of allergen
  • Hormones 
  • Intratympanic gentamicin therapy ( Chemical labyrinthectomy )
  • Micro-wick made up of polyvinyl acetate.

D) Surgical treatment:

1) Conservative procedures: 

  • Decompression of endolymphatic sac.
  • Endolymphatic shunt operation.
  • Sacculotomy ( Fick's operation).
  • Section of the vestibular nerve.
  • Ultrasonic destruction of vestibular labyrinth.

2) Destructive procedures:

  • Labyrinthectomy

3) Intermittent low-pressure pulse therapy ( Meniett device therapy )

Other options:

BPPV is not associated with hearing loss.

Syncope is associated with loss of consciousness.

Labyrinthitis is not associated with episodic vertigo like in Meniere's disease and is often bilateral.

questions.text: A farmer with a history of flea bite in a godown presents with the features of high fever, painful inguinal lymphadenopathy, vomiting and diarrhea and hypotension. Smears prepared from the discharge of these swellings revealed bacteria with bipolar staining. Which stain will help in the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of fever, chills, lymphadenopathy, and a smear showing bipolar staining of bacteria is highly suggestive of bubonic plague caused by Yersinia pestis. The stain used for this organism is the Wayson stain containing methylene blue.

Plague is a zoonotic disease caused by Yersinia pestis. It is a gram-negative, non-motile, coccobacillus. The reservoirs of infection are wild rodents like field mice, gerbils, skunks, etc. In India, the gerbil (Tatera indica) is the main reservoir. The important vector of plague is rat flea (Xenopsylla cheopis).

Humans acquire the disease by the bite of an infected flea, by direct contact with the tissues of the infected animal, or by droplet infection from cases of pneumonic plague. 

Human plague mainly presents as:

Bubonic plague- This is the most common type of disease. The patient develops a sudden fever, chills, headache, and painful lymphadenitis. Within a few days, the lymph nodes in the groin, axilla, or neck enlarge and are called buboes. This is followed by the suppuration of the buboes. Bubonic plague cannot spread from person to person as the bacilli are locked up in the buboes and do not find a way or easy exit.

Pneumonic plague- It develops as a complication of bubonic-septicemic plague. 

Septicemic plague- It occurs when the infection spreads to the blood.

Laboratory diagnosis- Microscopy reveals bacteria that show characteristic bipolar staining or safety pin appearance when stained with Wayson's stain. Antibodies to the F1 antigen of the bacteria can also be demonstrated by passive hemagglutination. PCR is used for a rapid presumptive diagnosis.

Treatment- Streptomycin, doxycycline, and chloramphenicol can be used.

questions.text: A primipara is being evaluated for hearing impairment which had worsened during her pregnancy. Rinne’s test is negative in both ears and Weber’s test is lateralized to the right side. On otoscopy, tympanic membranes appear normal. Audiometry shows a dip in BC at 2000 Hz. What is the treatment of choice for the above condition?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of otosclerosis and the treatment of choice for otosclerosis is stapedotomy.

Stapedotomy is the excision of the superstructure of stapes and drilling a hole in the footplate & placing a piston in the hole. This is the treatment of choice.

Other options:

Stapedectomy is the excision of the entire stapes (superstructure + footplate) and placing a piston in its place. It is outdated.

Sodium fluoride (NaF) is used in an active case of otosclerosis to hasten maturation.

Note: 

  • Both stapedectomy and stapedotomy have been described for the treatment of otosclerosis. Even in the stapedectomy procedure, stapedotomy (drilling) has been practiced. Hence stapedotomy is preferred over stapedectomy and is considered the treatment of choice.
  • In the above case since Rinne’s test is negative on both ears, it indicates bilateral conductive deafness. Weber’s test will lateralize to the ear with greater conductive loss.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy presents with low-grade fever, inspiratory stridor, and barking cough for the past 5 days. His chest X-ray showed the following. Which among the following is not indicated in the treatment of this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and an X-ray showing steeple signs are suggestive of croup (laryngotracheobronchitis). Since it is a viral infection, antibiotics like cefotaxime are not indicated in their treatment.

The median age for laryngotracheobronchitis is 3 months to 5 years. It is caused due to viral infection of the glottic and subglottic regions. Parainfluenza virus is a common cause of laryngotracheobronchitis

Patients present with low-grade fever,  barking cough, hoarseness of voice, and inspiratory stridor. X-ray neck would show narrowing of the subglottic region of the trachea which is characteristic of croup.

Treatment of croup involves:

  • Racemic epinephrine nebulization - It constricts pre-capillary arterioles in the upper airway mucosa and decreases capillary hydrostatic pressure, leading to fluid resorption from the interstitial space and reduction of edema. The indications for the administration of nebulized epinephrine are:
    • moderate to severe stridor at rest
    • the possible need for intubation
    • respiratory distress
    • hypoxia
  • Oral dexamethasone - Indicated in all the grades of croup. Corticosteroids reduce laryngeal edema through their anti-inflammatory action. IM dexamethasone and nebulized budesonide have an equal clinical effect. Corticosteroids should not be administered to children with varicella or tuberculosis as they may worsen the disease.
  • Severe croup requires urgent hospitalization with oxygen inhalation for hypoxemic child(SpO2 <92 %)
    (A helium-oxygen mixture (heliox) may be considered for severe croup when intubation is being considered)
  • Antibiotics are not indicated.

Most children that have croup can be managed safely at home. Indications for hospitalization:

  • Progressive stridor
  • Severe stridor at rest
  • Respiratory distress
  • Hypoxia
  • Cyanosis
  • Depressed mental status
  • Poor oral intake
  • Need for reliable observation

questions.text: A patient presents with symptoms as shown in the image below: 1) shows the site of the lesion,  2) has loss of proprioception, vibration, and discriminative touch on the same side, and 3) has loss of pain and temperature beginning one or two segments below the side of the lesion on the contralateral side. Hemisection of the spinal cord causes damage to ascending sensory (dorsal column pathway, ventrolateral spinothalamic tract) and descending motor (corticospinal tract) pathways, which is called the Brown-Séquard syndrome.

  • Weakness and spastic type of paralysis in certain muscle groups

The part marked as 3 is the contralateral side of the lesion and exhibits the following features:

questions.text: A patient has complaints of fever with a mild headache associated with some difficulty in swallowing. A throat examination reveals swollen glands and a thick, whitish membrane over his tonsils which bleeds on scraping the lesion.  A sample is taken from the exudate and a gram stain is done, which is as shown below. What is the organism associated with the disease?
questions.solution:
The history of white membrane over the tonsils and gram stain image showing gram-positive bacilli in Chinese letter arrangement points towards the diagnosis of faucial diphtheria caused by Corynebacterium diphtheriae.

Corynebacterium diphtheria is a gram-positive bacillus with clubbing at both ends. They possess characteristic polymetaphosphate granules also called metachromatic granules or Babes-Ernst granules. On microscopy, the bacilli are arranged at angles to each other which is seen as the Chinese letter or cuneiform pattern. 

Albert’s stain or Neisser’s stain or Loeffler's methylene blue are used to demonstrate the metachromatic granules of Corynebacterium diphtheria. These granules are called as polar bodies as they are situated at the ends of the bacilli.

The systemic manifestations of diphtheria are due to diphtheria toxin. It is an exotoxin that consists of two fragments - A and B. It acts by inhibiting protein synthesis. Fragment B helps in binding of the toxin to the cells and fragment A inactivates the elongation factor (EF-2) responsible for protein synthesis.

The clinical manifestation of diphtheria depends on the site of infection. Pharyngeal/faucial diphtheria is the most common presentation. The patient has marked adenitis, a bull neck, and severe toxemia. Pseudomembrane over the tonsils are characteristic. Bleeding from the tonsils can occur. It leads to life-threatening complications such as asphyxia, circulatory failure, post-diphtheritic paralysis, and toxemia.

Cutaneous diphtheria is due to non-toxigenic strains of diphtheria. It may present as a diphtheritic whitlow or skin ulcer.

The image below shows the pseudomembrane over the tonsil typically seen in diphtheria.

Image below shows bull neck.

Isolation of corynebacterium from patient or close contact confirms the diagnosis. Specimen collection for culture should be done from nose, throat and if possible from below the membrane. It grows readily on Loeffler's serum slope and confirmation can be done by growing on potassium tellurite agar which serves as a selective medium.

Image below shows Loeffler's serum slope.

questions.text: A housewife presents with complaints of a blocked nose, loss of smell, and dry, greenish crusty nasal discharge. On examination, nasal cavities appear roomy and turbinates are atrophied. Which of the following surgeries can be done on this patient?

The given clinical scenario is suggestive of atrophic rhinitis. Young’s and modified Young’s operations are done for the treatment of atrophic rhinitis.

In Young’s operation, both the nostrils are closed completely just within the nasal vestibule by raising flaps. They are opened after 6 months or later when the mucosa may revert back to normal and crusting will be reduced.

Modified Young’s operation aims at partially closing the nostrils.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy rapidly develops hypoglycemia after moderate activity. Blood examination reveals raised levels of ketone bodies, lactic acid, and triglycerides. On examination, the liver and kidneys are found to be enlarged. Which of the following would be seen in excess amounts in the liver of this child ?
questions.solution:
The given features are consistent with von Gierke's disease and thus glucose-6-phosphate will be deposited more as there is a deficiency of the Glucose-6-phosphatase enzyme.

Von Gierke's disease is a glycogen storage disorder, inherited in an autosomal recessive manner, which is caused due to deficiency of the Glucose-6-phosphatase enzyme.

Clinical presentation is often in infancy (usually at 3-4 months). Affected children have fat cheeks, relatively thin extremities, short stature and a protuberant abdomen due to massive hepatomegaly, and enlarged kidneys. Easy bruising and epistaxis is common due to increased bleeding time. Delayed puberty and osteopenia are also seen. 

Clinical presentation and laboratory findings of hypoglycemia, lactic acidosis, ketosis, hyperuricemia and hyperlipidemia point to a suspected diagnosis of von Gierke's disease. Liver biopsy is an invasive procedure for diagnosis. Histopathology of the liver shows excess glycogen deposition. Non-invasive may be made by single gene sequencing.

Treatment focuses on maintaining euglycemia. Nasogastric infusion of glucose or uncooked cornstarch is administed in infancy. For older children, uncooked cornstarch may be given orally. Dietary avoidance of fructose and galactose is necessary in these patients. Orthotropic liver transplantation is a potential cure for von Gierke's disease.

questions.text: The students of a boarding school eat from the same canteen. One of the students developed abdominal pain, jaundice, and fever following which other students also presented with similar symptoms. Which of the following investigations should the Medical Officer of the area check for to reach a diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is of a Hepatitis A outbreak that is spread via the fecal-oral route and the investigation of choice is IgM for Hepatitis A.

Hepatitis A:

Modes of transmission

  • Fecal-oral route: This is the major route of transmission. It can occur directly (handshake after toilet) or indirectly via contaminated food, water, or milk.
  • Parenteral route: This is very rare and occurs during the viral dissemination phase. It occurs during the prodromal phase and not when patients are symptomatic and admitted to the hospital. As a result, healthcare workers are not at increased risk.
  • Sexual transmission may occur in individuals practicing oro-anal methods (usually homosexual men). It however would not cause an outbreak.

Incubation period:

  • 10 to 50 days (usually 14-28 days). Isolation is not an effective measure to control outbreaks as the shedding of the virus is maximum during the early stages of illness when clinical illness may not have started and many patients are asymptomatic yet continue to shed the virus.

Clinical spectrum:

  • The onset of jaundice is preceded by gastrointestinal symptoms such as nausea, vomiting, anorexia, and mild fever.
  • Jaundice may appear within a few days of the prodromal period, but anicteric hepatitis is more common.
  • Hepatitis A resolves completely in 98 percent of cases but relapse of symptoms is noted in 3-20 percent of cases

Diagnosis:

  • Laboratory diagnosis of hepatitis A can be obtained by
    • Demonstration of HAV particles or specific viral antigens in the feces, bile, and blood.
    • Anti-HAV appears in the lgM fraction during the acute phase, peaking about 2 weeks after the elevation of liver enzymes. ELISA is the method of choice for measuring HAV antibodies.

Prevention and containment:

  • Control of reservoir: Use of 0.5 percent sodium hypochlorite has been strongly recommended as an effective disinfectant
  • Control of transmission: personal and community hygiene. Hand hygiene before food and after the toilet is highly recommended.
  • 1 mg/L of free residual chlorine can cause the destruction of the virus in 30 minutes at pH values of 8.5 or less. Hence adequate chlorination can be helpful.
  • Patients with chronic liver disease are at increased risk for fulminant hepatitis A and should be vaccinated. The use of the hepatitis A vaccine should be considered for pre-exposure(for travelers) and post-exposure(close contacts of affected individuals)prophylaxis.

questions.text: A boy was diagnosed with a medical condition, which is believed to have been passed down from his grandmother to his father, and now to him. What is the pattern of inheritance in this particular case?
questions.solution:
The said disease shows an autosomal dominant pattern.

In the autosomal dominant pattern of inheritance, both males and females are equally affected, and the affected individual has a 50% chance of passing it on to the offspring.

The following flow chart helps in making out the pattern of inheritance from a given pedigree chart.

Related Pearl: Pedigree chart for different inheritance patterns

 

Autosomal Dominant Disorders:

  • With every autosomal dominant disorder, some patients do not have affected parents. Such patients owe their disorder to new mutations involving either the egg or the sperm from which they were derived.
  • Clinical features can be modified by variations in penetrance and expressivity.
  • In many conditions, the age at onset is delayed, and symptoms and signs may not appear until adulthood (as in Huntington disease).

X-linked Recessive Conditions:

  • All sex-linked disorders are X-linked, and almost all are recessive.
  • Several genes are located in the “male-specific region of Y;” all these are related to spermatogenesis.
  • Males with mutations affecting the Y-linked genes are usually infertile, and hence, there is no Y-linked inheritance.
  • An affected male does not transmit the disorder to his sons, but all daughters are carriers.
  • Sons of heterozygous women have, of course, a one-in-two chance of receiving the mutant gene.
  • Heterozygous females express the disorder partially because of random inactivation of one X chromosome.

questions.text: What is the gene mutation seen in hemochromatosis?
questions.solution:
Mutation in the HFE gene on the short arm of the 6th chromosome is seen in hemochromatosis.

Hemochromatosis is an inherited genetic disorder. Mutation of the HFE gene leads to excessive absorption of iron which gets deposited in the liver, pancreas, followed by the heart, joints, and endocrine organs. Histopathology shows golden yellow hemosiderin granules in the cytoplasm of hepatocytes which stain positive with Prussian blue stain. Serum iron is raised and serum ferritin is significantly increased.

Hepatomegaly will be present in the majority of the patients with symptoms. Skin shows bronze pigmentation due to the increased deposition of iron and melanin over the dermis. Glucose levels are deranged or diabetes mellitus is seen due to the direct damage of the pancreatic islet cells by the deposition of iron.

Congestive cardiac failure is the most common cardiac manifestation of hemochromatosis. Features of cardiac failure will develop suddenly and rapidly progress, and if left untreated it may cause death. Hypogonadism due to failure of the hypothalamic-pituitary axis by deposition of iron. This may manifest as testicular atrophy or amenorrhea

It is managed by weekly or twice weekly phlebotomy of 500 mL. Chelating agents like subcutaneous deferoxamine, and oral deferasirox are effective. The main cause of death in hemochromatosis is cardiac failure. 

Other options:

Option B: PTEN is a tumor suppressor gene. Mutation of this gene is associated with Cowden syndrome which leads to multiple cancers like breast cancer, prostate cancer, endometrial cancer, and colorectal cancer.

Option C: ATP7B gene mutation causes Wilson's disease which is an autosomal recessive disorder.

Option D: MRP2 protein is associated with Dubin-Johnson syndrome.

questions.text: A 7-month-old child presents with Hb 6.3 with a history of repeated blood transfusions. Investigations show MCV- 70fl, MCH- normal, MCHC-normal, and peripheral smear showed a hypochromic microcytic picture. Which of the following investigations should be done next in this child?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of repeated transfusions, low Hb, low MCV, and a hypochromic microcytic picture in the smear is suggestive of thalassemia and Hb electrophoresis should be done in this child

Hb Electrophoresis is used for newborn screening.

High-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) is the investigation of choice but is not as definitive as globin gene sequencing. 

Alpha- and beta-thalassemia are inherited disorders in which there is reduced production of alpha-globin or beta-globin chains, respectively. This leads to precipitation of the excess (unpaired) chains, interfering with red blood cell (RBC) production and survival. Disease severity is inversely correlated with the number of functioning globin chains.

Each individual carries 2 beta-chain genes and 4 alpha-chain genes.

Hemoglobin levels:

  • Normal hemoglobin pattern- HbA=95%, HbA2=3.5%, HbF =1.5%
  • Beta-thalassemia trait- HbA=90%, HbA2=5%, HbF=5%
  • Beta-thalassemia intermedia- HbA=45%, HbA2=5%, HbF=50%

Clinical features in thalassemia:

  • Anemia
  • Jaundice and pigment gallstones
  • Skeletal deformities including facial deformities, changes in body habitus, osteopenia/osteoporosis
  • Iron overload
  • Growth impairment
  • Hepatosplenomegaly
  • Endocrine abnormalities including hypogonadism, hypothyroidism, diabetes mellitus
  • Heart failure and arrhythmias

Laboratory studies:

  • Peripheral smear is likely to show microcytic hypochromic anemia with target cells, teardrop cells, and some coarse basophilic stippling in certain cases. These findings are non-specific. 
  • High RBC count 
  • Low reticulocyte count
  • High LDH, high indirect bilirubin, low haptoglobin, and negative Coomb's test
  • High transferrin saturation, normal serum iron levels, elevated ferritin levels

questions.text: A researcher who was studying on Plasmodium species decided to visit the malaria-endemic place in Odisha after 2 days to do his clinical study for 5 weeks.  Which of the following drugs need to be taken as prophylaxis before visiting the malaria-endemic place?
questions.solution:
Doxycycline drug needs to be taken as prophylaxis by the researcher before going to malaria-endemic places.

Chemoprophylaxis in travelers:

  • If the duration of travel is less than 6 weeks then doxycycline 100mg once a day can be started 2 days before travel and continued at least 4 weeks after travel.

The goals of NSP strategy are phased elimination of malaria in India. The National Framework for Malaria Elimination (NFME) in India has set 2030 as goal for eliminating malaria, and the goals of NSP in consonance with overall goals.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy presents with weight loss, fever, and a painless swelling in the area of his jaw. CBC reveals anemia and lymphocytosis. Biopsy findings from the swelling are seen in the image below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation and biopsy findings of starry sky appearance point towards a diagnosis of Burkitt's lymphoma.

The biopsy image shows tumor cells with multiple small nucleoli, minimal cytoplasm, and high mitotic index closely apposed to each other forming a dark blue background (the "sky"). These cells have a high turnover rate. The macrophages get stuffed in between along with cellular debr is, they are called tingible body macrophages. Upon fixation, the cytoplasm washes away leaving behind white spaces filled with debris ( the "stars"). This produces a starry sky appearance, which is classical to Burkitt lymphoma. 

Burkitt lymphoma:

  • Most common NHL in children <15 years
  • Associated with translocation of MYC gene of chromosome 8 (Option A)
  • Translocations: t (8;14), t (2;8), t (8,22)
  • Three distinct clinical forms:
    • Endemic: affects children in Africa, affects the jaw, and maxilla and is EBV-associated (Option B)
    • Sporadic: in adults in Western countries 
    • Immunodeficiency associated: HIV infection
  • It is the most rapidly proliferating human tumour, Ki-67 stains 100% of cells (DLBCL- 40% staining with Ki-67)

Histology: Starry sky pattern

Immunophenotype: 

  • The tumour cells express
    • Surface IgM type and immunoglobulin light chains (kappa > lambda)
    • B cell-associated antigens -CD19, CD20, CD22, CD79a
    • Germinal centre-associated markers- CD10 & BCL-6
    • HLA-DR and CD43.
  • Expression of CD21 -the Epstein-Barr virus (EBV)/C3d receptor, is dependent on the EBV status of the tumours.
    • Endemic BL are EBV positive, express CD21
    • Non-endemic BL in non-immunosuppressed patients are EBV negative and lack CD21 expression.

A 38-year-old man presents with bleeding gums for 20 days. He has gingival hyperplasia, hepatosplenomegaly, and lymphadenopathy. Blood reports are given. The most likely diagnosis from the clinical presentation and cytochemistry is acute myeloid leukemia (AML) M5 or acute monocytic leukemia.

Diagnostic features of AML M5:  20% or more blasts in the bone marrow. Markedly elevated white blood cell count with organomegaly, lymphadenopathy, gingival hyperplasia, CNS involvement and other tissue infiltration. Monoblasts have folded or lobulated nuclei, lack Auer rods, and are nonspecific esterase positive. Classified as AML with recurrent genetic abnormalities such as inv(16)(p13;1q22), t(16;16)(p13.1q22) or t(9;11)(p22;q23)

Myeloperoxidase is present in the azurophilic granules of neutrophils and its precursors. It is positive in AML M1, M2, M3, M4 and negative in AML M0. Monoblasts and monocytes may be negative or positive. When positive, the granules are smaller than in neutrophils and diffusely scattered throughout the cytoplasm.

questions.text: In the following LV pressure-volume loop diagram, point C denotes  ______
questions.solution:
Point C denotes the opening of the aortic valve.

The volume-pressure curve represents the changes in volume and pressure in the left ventricle during a single cardiac cycle. The relationship between ventricular pressure (Y-axis) and volume (X-axis) throughout the cardiac cycle is represented by this loop.

  • A - Mitral valve opens
  • B - Mitral valve closes
  • C - Aortic valve opens
  • D - Aortic valve closes

Phase I: Period of filling

It begins at a ventricular volume of about 50 ml (end-systolic volume) and a diastolic pressure of 2 to 3 mm Hg. As venous blood flows into the ventricle from the left atrium, the ventricular volume normally increases to about 120 ml, called the end-diastolic volume and the diastolic pressure rising to about 5 to 7 mm Hg.

Phase II: Period of isovolumic contraction

During isovolumic contraction, the volume of the ventricle does not change because all valves are closed. However, the pressure inside the ventricle increases to equal the pressure in the aorta (80 mm Hg) as depicted by point C.

Phase III: Period of ejection

During ejection, the systolic pressure rises even higher because of still more contraction of the ventricle. At the same time, the volume of the ventricle decreases because the aortic valve has now opened and blood flows out of the ventricle into the aorta.

Phase IV: Period of isovolumic relaxation

At the end of the period of ejection (point D), the aortic valve closes and the ventricular pressure falls back to the diastolic pressure level. The line labeled “IV” traces this decrease in intraventricular pressure without any change in volume. Thus, the ventricle returns to its starting point, with about 50 ml of blood left in the ventricle and at an atrial pressure of 2 to 3 mm Hg.

The area subtended by this functional volume-pressure diagram (the shaded area, labeled “EW”) represents the net external work output of the ventricle during its contraction cycle.

questions.text: Which of the following indicators is the best to know the overall burden of disease?
questions.solution:
DALY is the best measure of the overall disease burden in a defined population and the effectiveness of interventions.

DALY (Disability Adjusted Life Years):

  • It can measure both mortality and disability together.
  • One DALY can be considered a lost year of a "healthy" life.
  • The sum of these DALYs across the population, or the burden of disease, can be thought of as a measurement of the gap between current health status and an ideal health situation where the entire population lives to an advanced age, free of disease and disability.

DALYs for a disease or health condition are calculated as the sum of the Years of Life Lost (YLL) due to premature mortality in the population and the Years Lost due to Disability (YLD) for people living with the health condition or its consequences:

Calculation

DALY = YLL + YLD

The YLL basically corresponds to the number of deaths multiplied by the standard life expectancy at the age at which death occurs. The basic formula for YLL (without yet including other social preferences discussed below), is the following for a given cause, age, and sex:

YLL = N x L

where:

  • N = number of deaths
  • L = standard life expectancy at the age of death in years

Prevalence YLD

YLD = P x DW

where:

  • P = number of prevalent cases
  • DW = disability weight

questions.text: A farmer presents to the emergency department with diarrhea, sweating, excessive lacrimation, and salivation. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding the treatment of the condition?

choices.text: Atropine is used as an antidote for OP poisoning
Pralidoxime has a role in reversing the enzyme in carbamate poisoning
Succinylcholine use is avoided in rapid sequence intubation

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of organophosphate poisoning. Pralidoxime is used to counter the nicotinic effects of organophosphates. It reactivates the acetylcholinesterase, which had been deactivated in organophosphate poisoning. 

Atropine is useful in organophosphate poisoning because it is a competitive antagonist of acetylcholine. An acetylcholinesterase enzyme has an active and anionic site. The organophosphates bind to the active site of AChEs (acetylcholine esterases) and deactivate it. This results in excessive Ach causing excessive muscarinic activity. It has relatively insignificant action on nicotinic receptors. 

Organophosphates and carbamates are powerful acetylcholinesterase inhibitors. While carbamates bind reversibly, organophosphates bind irreversibly.  

The predominant initial signs are of muscarinic excess which includes: (DUMBBELSS)

  • Diarrhea
  • Urination
  • Miosis
  • Bronchospasm
  • Bradycardia
  • Emesis
  • Lacrimation
  • Salivation
  • Sweating

Nicotinic manifestations include twitching of eyelids, tongue, and facial muscles which then leads to paralysis. CNS stimulation results in headaches, tremors, ataxia, coma, and death. 

Patients who present with organophosphate and carbamate poisoning require early endotracheal intubation to avoid respiratory depression, which is a common complication. Succinylcholine is avoided due to its metabolism by acetylcholinesterase which leads to prolonged neuromuscular blockade.

questions.text: Which of the following statement is false about the Ayushman Bharat-National Health Protection Mission?

choices.text: Government provides health insurance cover of up to Rs. 5,00,000 per family per year.
The limit of the size of the family that is covered is upto 7 members.
Hospitals cannot deny treatment to the diseases and the families covered under the scheme.
It covers secondary and tertiary care hospitalization.

questions.solution:
There is no cap on family size or the age of the members. All the families listed under the Socio-Economic Caste Census database are covered as per the defined criteria.

Ayushman Bharat-National Health Protection Mission: To build a comprehensive need-based health care service. 

Components: The target of the two initiatives mentioned below are to build a New India 2022.

  • Creation of 1,50,000 Health and Wellness Centres- These centers will provide Comprehensive Primary Health Care (CPHC), covering both maternal and child health services and non-communicable diseases, including free essential drugs and diagnostic services.
  • The second component is the National Health Protection Mission (NHPM) which provides health protection coverage to poor and vulnerable families. The Health and Wellness Centres will play a critical role in creating awareness about AB-NHPM, screening for non-communicable diseases, and follow-up of hospitalization cases among others.

Beneficiary Level: 

  • The government provides health insurance coverage of up to Rs. 5,00,000 per family per year.
  • All families listed in the SECC database as per the defined criteria will be covered. No cap on family size and age of members.
  • Priority to a girl child, women, and senior citizens.
  • Free treatment is available at all public and empaneled private hospitals in times of need.
  • Covers secondary and tertiary care hospitalization.
  • 1,350 medical packages covering surgery, medical and daycare treatments, cost of medicines, and diagnostics.
  • All pre-existing diseases are covered. Hospitals cannot deny treatment.
  • Cashless and paperless access to quality health care services.
  • Hospitals will not be allowed to charge any additional money from beneficiaries for the treatment.
  • Can reach out for information, assistance, complaints, and grievances to a 24X7 helpline number - 14555

questions.text: A 45-year-old healthy man with a history of small streaks of blood in his stools is being sent for a colonoscopy to screen for colon cancer. This type of prevention is _______
questions.solution:
Colonoscopies for early detection/screening of colon cancer are an example of secondary prevention.

Early diagnosis (including screening) and treatment is the component of secondary prevention. Some examples of secondary prevention are as follows:

  • Papanicolaou (Pap) smear for early detection of cervical cancer
  • Mammography, for early detection of breast cancer
  • Colonoscopies, for early detection of colon cancer
  • Blood Pressure Screening

Secondary prevention measures focus on the sub-clinical stage and the early clinical stage, such as dysplasia in this case. These measures enable early detection and prompt effective intervention to correct departures from a state of health.

questions.text: A child with mental retardation, blindness, and muscle weakness was investigated and was found to be deficient for the Hexosaminidase-A enzyme. She is most likely suffering from ____.
questions.solution:
Tay-Sachs disease is due to the deficiency of the enzyme Hexosaminidase A which degrades GM2 gangliosides.

Clinical features of Tay-Sachs disease are :

  • Loss of motor skills
  • Seizures
  • Hyperacusis
  • Macrocephaly
  • Macular cherry-red spots
  • Neurodegeneration
  • Blindness
  • Muscular weakness

    • GM2 gangliosidosis (Tay-Sachs disease and Sandhoff disease)
    • Farber disease
    • Niemann–Pick disease
  • Retinotoxicity due to specific agents, including quinine, dapsone, gentamicin, carbon monoxide, and methanol
